Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee.  Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Classically rich and crisply chocolate-toned dark roast for Keurig owners.

p1: Blind Assessment: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a Keurig-compatible capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving): Sweet-toned, gentle. Raisin, apricot, vanilla, hazelnut, a hint of flowers in aroma and cup. Balanced, sweetly tart acidity; smooth, lively mouthfeel. Hints of flavor survive and a sweet, gently drying finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee is sold pre-ground in capsules that are compatible with the Keurig brewing system, but which use a different design from Keurig K-Cups. Mystic Monk Coffee is a small-batch roaster associated with a Carmelite monastery located in the Rocky Mountains of northern Wyoming. Roastmaster Brother Java emphasizes his artisan approach to roasting and his commitment to quality.  Visit www.mysticmonkcoffee.com or call 877-751-6377 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A quietly balanced, gently nuanced breakfast cup for Keurig owners.

coffee_origin: Ethiopia; Sumatra; Papua New Guinea; Colombia.
p1: Blind Assessment: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a Keurig-compatible capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving): Crisp, rather deep, quietly complex. Roasted cacao nib, walnut, orangy fruit, a hint of flowers in aroma and cup. Roast-muted acidity; smooth mouthfeel. Sweet, chocolate-toned, though rather drying finish.
p2: Notes: A wide range of origins in a dark-roasted K-Cup blend.  Visit www.starbucks.com or call 800-782-7282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A satisfying dark-roasted cup for Keurig-owners. The K-cup format seems to mute the usual bitterness of the dark roast, allowing a quiet but pleasing aromatic complexity to move forward.

p1: Blind Assessment: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a "K-Cup" capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving). Roasted nut, chocolate, banana-like fruit, night-blooming flowers in aroma and, more distinctly, in the cup. Round, softly tart acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor simplifies but sustains in a clean, balanced finish.
p2: Notes: This blend is composed of coffees certified organically grown and Fair Trade, the latter meaning the green beans were purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Decaffeinated using water only, no solvents. Keurig/Green Mountain, formerly Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, pioneered single-serve capsule brewing in the United States with its Keurig brewing system, and remains one of the country’s leading large specialty roasters, offering a particularly wide-ranging variety of origins and roast styles. Visit www.GreenMountainCoffee.com or call 888-879-4627 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: An almost miraculously good decaffeinated coffee for Keurig owners; the gently lively acidity, smooth mouthfeel and quietly complex flavor are particularly impressive. No raw nut or woody decaf notes that we could detect, with the only (almost hypothetical) decaffeination-related flaw a slight fading in aroma and finish.

p1: Blind Assessment: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a Keurig-compatible capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving): Brightly pungent, lively. Dark chocolate, fresh-cut cedar, black currant, cherry, a hint of a bourbon-whisky-like note in aroma and cup. Tart but balanced acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Rich, resonant short finish, slightly fading and dry in the long.
p2: Notes: Coffee People is a brand of Diedrich Coffee, which in turn is owned by Green Mountain Coffee Roasters. It appears that Donut Shop is a blend designed to compete with the medium-roasted Dunkin’ Donuts blend. Visit www.GreenMountainCoffee.com or call 888-879-4627 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A lively, engagingly complex breakfast cup with a hint of the elegant dry berry character usually found in only the most distinguished of coffee origins.

p1: Blind Assessment: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a "K-Cup" capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving). Deep, balanced. Buttery caramel, earthy dark chocolate, lightly charred cedar, raisin in aroma and cup. Rich, pungent acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate and raisin in particular sustain in a bittersweet, gently drying finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade, the latter meaning the green beans were purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Sumatras like this one achieve their unusual cup character mainly through unorthodox processing and drying methods unique to Indonesia. Keurig/Green Mountain, formerly Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, pioneered single-serve capsule brewing in the United States with its Keurig brewing system, and remains one of the country’s leading large specialty roasters, offering a particularly wide-ranging variety of origins and roast styles. Visit www.GreenMountainCoffee.com or call 888-879-4627 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Impressively authentic version of the classic darker roasted, robust Sumatra cup for Keurig owners.

p1: Blind Assessment: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a Keurig-compatible capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving).  Bright, juicy, complex. Concord grape, ripe grapefruit, a hint of dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Delicate, lively acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. The fruit notes consolidate and carry into a clean, sweet-toned finish.
p2: Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. AA is the highest grade of Kenya coffee based on bean size and freedom from physical imperfections. Keurig/Green Mountain, formerly Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, pioneered single-serve capsule brewing in the United States with its Keurig brewing system, and remains one of the country’s leading large specialty roasters, offering a particularly wide-ranging variety of origins and roast styles. Visit www.GreenMountainCoffee.com or call 888-879-4627 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Unusual opportunity for Keurig owners to enjoy a distinctive version of one of the world’s great single-origin coffees.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Complex flowers and citrus, high-toned but smooth. Flowers, butter, grapefruity citrus, roasted cocoa nib in aroma and small cup. Smooth, lightly syrupy mouthfeel; rich, long, chocolate-saturated finish. Superb in two parts milk, sweetly and richly chocolate-toned with a gently tart fruit that resonates with particular distinction in a long finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast. Visit www.barringtoncoffee.com or call 800-528-0998 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy smoothly bright, citrus- and floral-toned straight shots and short milk drinks.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Round, crisply sweet, balanced. Dark chocolate, hazelnut, fresh-cut cedar, bourbon-whisky-like hint in aroma and small cup. Full, syrupy mouthfeel. Dark chocolate dominates in a buttery, richly drying finish. Tartly chocolaty with an almost floral vanilla complication in two parts milk.
p2: Notes: Twisted’s name was inspired by the way espresso “twists” as it streams from the spout of a portafilter. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A complete and satisfying straight shot, syrupy and complex. Tends to dominate in short milk, but sweetens and rounds in taller milk.

p1: Blind Assessment: Savory-sweet and lushly floral-toned. Flowers, plum, dark chocolate, raisin in aroma and cup. Delicately balanced, crisply sweet acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Rich, deeply flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: From trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety and processed at prize-winning Gitesi mill. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the past decade owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies, and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Quietly original in its graceful integration of savory depth and floral sweetness.

coffee_origin: Jiwaka Province, western highlands of Papua New Guinea.
p1: Blind Assessment: Rich, deep, pungently complex. Blackberry, cherry, fresh-cut fir, a hint of cinnamon bark in aroma and cup. Gently tart, juicy acidity; round, buttery mouthfeel. Floral notes emerge in a very sweet, long finish.
p2: Notes: The high mountain valleys of central Papua New Guinea offer some of the world's most favorable terroirs for production of fine coffee, although the rugged terrain presents daunting transportation and infrastructure challenges. This is a particularly fine Papua New Guinea from the tribal-owned Koban Plantation in the heart of the highlands. AA is the highest grade of Papua New Guinea coffee based on bean size and freedom from physical imperfections. Beansmith Coffee is a small-batch roasting company serving the Omaha region that believes that coffee drinkers should know as much as they can about the coffee they drink, and that there is a story behind every cup, one worth exploring.  Visit www.beansmith.com or call 866-663-5295 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Finely balanced, classically complete cup should satisfy almost any coffee drinker.

p1: Blind Assessment: Intense with distinct whisky-like notes. Dry, nut-toned chocolate, raspberry, rye whisky, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Rich, delicately bittersweet acidity; silky, lively mouthfeel. The dry chocolate note in particular dominates in a crisp finish.
p2: Notes: Produced in the central highlands of the colorful island of Bali, this is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Max Fulmer of Royal Coffee helped establish this style of coffee in Bali. Seattle Coffee Works is a small-batch retail and wholesale roasting company, focused on quality and green coffee sourcing without compromise. Visit www.seattlecoffeeworks.com or call 206-340-8867 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy variations on the gently fermented, natural or dried-in-the-fruit cup. This version is drier and more rye-whisky-toned than most, which tend to be sweeter and more brandy-like.

p1: Blind Assessment: Slightly savory, gently pungent. Fresh-cut fir, roasted cocoa nib, baked apple, perhaps a hint of sage in aroma and cup. Brisk but deep acidity; silky mouthfeel. The unusual baked apple note, a savory-toned fruit, persists in a balanced finish.
p2: Notes: Produced by some of the 2,000 small-holding farmer members of the Cenfrocafe Cooperative.  Beansmith Coffee is a small-batch roasting company serving the Omaha region that believes that coffee drinkers should know as much as they can about the coffee they drink, and that there is a story behind every cup, one worth exploring.  Visit www.beansmith.com or call 866-663-5295 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a briskly savory-edged breakfast cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet-toned, delicately pungent. Honeysuckle, fresh-cut cedar, walnut, black currant in aroma and cup. Balanced, gently brisk acidity; silky mouthfeel. Hints of flavor carry into a sweetly balanced finish.
p2: Notes: From trees of the heirloom Bourbon and Typica varieties; grown on Finca Santa Rosa in Chiapas State, Mexico. Beansmith Coffee is a small-batch roasting company serving the Omaha region that believes that coffee drinkers should know as much as they can about the coffee they drink, and that there is a story behind every cup, one worth exploring. Visit www.beansmith.com or call 866-663-5295 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Classic Mexico: clean, softly bright, quietly complex, with a hint of the elegant dry berry note associated with the heirloom Bourbon variety.

coffee_origin: Canton Illimani, Caranavi Province, west-central Bolivia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Deeply and crisply sweet; complex. Chocolate, hazelnut, orange zest, flowers in aroma and cup. Soft but lively acidity; lightly syrupy, buoyant mouthfeel. Sweet, gently flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Produced by small-holding farmers and prepared by the classic wash-and-ferment process. Water Avenue Coffee is a tiny roastery nestled next to the railway in the old Industrial Southeast quarter in Portland, Oregon. Visit www.wateravenuecoffee.com or call 503-808-7083 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A classic Bolivia cup: lovely structure with gentle but vibrant acidity; quietly complex aromatics.

p1: Blind Assessment: Musky and savory. Wet oak, sweet pumpkin, cantaloupe, mushroom, dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Rich, bittersweet acidity; medium-full mouthfeel. Roundly dry short finish; sweetens and turns chocolaty in the long.
p2: Notes: Produced by small-holding farmers in the town of Villa Rosario and processed at the admired Buenavista mill. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy depth and savory complexity in a brewed coffee.

p1: Blind Assessment: Distinct sweetly tart fruit notes (grapefruit, passion fruit, guava), pungent fresh-cut fir, with rounding hints of chocolate and plum in aroma and cup. Quiet, delicate acidity; light but smoothly silky mouthfeel. Sweet, long, gently flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: The high mountain valleys of central Papua New Guinea offer some of the world's most favorable terroirs for production of fine coffee, although the rugged terrain presents daunting transportation and infrastructure challenges. This Papua New Guinea is organically grown by small-holding farmers in Wau who are members of a cooperative associated with Monpi Sustainable Services, an organization devoted to sustainability. Decaffeinated by the "Water Process" method, which does not involve use of solvents. Groundwork is a small-batch coffee roaster based in North Hollywood, California whose motto “Sustainability, Quality, Community” is expressed in part by maintaining organic certification for their facilities and products. Visit www.groundworkcoffee.com or call 818-506-6020 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: An unusual opportunity for decaf drinkers to enjoy the sweetly tart, grapefruity character of a fine Papua New Guinea coffee offered as a single-origin.

p1: Blind Assessment: Pungent, gently scorched cedar, dark chocolate, caramel and an herbal hint in aroma and cup. Round, roast-muted acidity; pleasantly smooth though rather lean mouthfeel. The chocolate sweetness dominates in a long, resonant, slightly drying finish.
p2: Notes: Although described as medium roasted, by current industry standards this coffee is a moderately dark roast. Early Bird is a gourmet coffee roaster based in Woodinville, Washington that roasts its coffee to order and prides itself on meticulous customer service standards.  Visit www.earlybirdcoffee.com or call 800-632-3134 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a balanced, chocolate-toned darker roasted cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Gentle, crisp, sweet-toned. Honey, lemon tart, delicate hints of milk chocolate and flowers in aroma and cup. Soft acidity; smooth, velvety mouthfeel. Sweet, flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Certified organically grown. The Puno region borders Lake Titicaca at the far southeastern tip of Peru. Papa Lin's Coffee Roasting is a small, “nano” roaster located in Yorktown Heights, New York, focusing on carefully sourced, extremely high quality specialty coffees, which is then custom roasted to the preference of every customer.  Visit www.papalins.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy purity and delicacy in a crisply refreshing morning cup.

coffee_origin: Nekempte District, Oromia Region, western Ethiopia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Succulent, richly intricate. Wild strawberry, dried blueberry, rich mousse-like chocolate, fresh ginseng, lush flowers in aroma and cup. Complete, exhilarating acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor-saturated finish, crisply drying with a persistent ginseng note.
p2: Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #10 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. Ethiopian coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express floral and citrus notes with particular intensity. This extraordinary coffee produced from a mix of native Ethiopian heirloom varieties is brought into the U.S. by boutique exporter/importer Ninety Plus Coffee. Papa Lin's Coffee Roasting is a small, “nano” roaster located in Yorktown Heights, New York, focusing on carefully sourced, extremely high quality specialty coffees, which is then custom roasted to the preference of every customer. Visit www.papalins.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: This striking but accessible coffee should please anyone, while aficionados of the great Ethiopia wet-processed profile will find its wide range of aromatics familiar yet arrestingly original.

p1: Blind Assessment: Intense, crisp, juicy. Tartly sweet berry notes -- black berry, black currant; lush flowers, honey, roasted cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Rich, balanced acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor carries deep into a long, resonant finish.
p2: Notes: Produced by the Kamacharia Farmers Cooperative Society and almost entirely from trees of the admired, Bourbon-derived SL28 variety. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Quintessential Kenya, alive with characteristic Kenya berry notes lushly sweet yet crisply dry and animated by a ripe and accessible acidity.

p1: Blind Assessment: Extraordinarily lush, nectar-like fruit; cherry, black currant, nectarine; balanced by a crisp, roasted cocoa nib and roasted malt notes. Balanced, lively acidity; full, plush mouthfeel. Flavor simplifies but remains resonantly present in a long, rich finish.
p2: Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #2 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. Rwanda's potential as fine coffee producer has only come to fruition over the past several years owing to generous support from international aid agencies, the specialty coffee community and the industry of its growers. Produced entirely from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety. BeanFruit is a quality-oriented small-batch roaster based in Jackson, Mississippi, whose motto comes from Galatians 5:22-23: “But the fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, peace, longsuffering, gentleness, goodness, faith, meekness, temperance: against such there is no law.” Visit www.beanfruit.com or call 601-624-2605 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Offers everything: Seething, opulent flavor atop a firm, classic structure.

p1: Blind Assessment: Intricately sweet, delicately complex. Ripe strawberry, orange, candied nut, vanilla-toned flowers in aroma and cup. Gently crisp acidity; light but smoothly silky mouthfeel. Very sweet, lightly flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #11 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. This coffee was processed using the honey method, which means that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but all or some of the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions. The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who value sweetness without sentimentality.

coffee_origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Intensely aromatic, finely structured. Orange- and papaya-like fruit notes, dark chocolate, crisply lush floral notes in aroma and cup. Bright, balanced acidity; syrupy but lively mouthfeel. Sweet but drying in the short finish, with a chocolate note that rings on far into the long.
p2: Notes: Produced on Carmelo Yujra’s small, organically certified farm and subjected to an experimental final step in processing based on practice in Kenya in which the clean, freshly washed parchment coffee is exposed to an additional 24-hour soak in cold water. Based in the San Diego area, Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler focused on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was awarded the “2012 Roaster of the Year” title from Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A complete and classic Latin-American-style cup, with big body, bright but balanced acidity, and a lush and juicy set of flavor and aroma notes.

coffee_origin: Eastern Highlands Province, Papua New Guinea
p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet, floral, clean. Lavender and plum flower, honey, cherry, candied pecan in aroma and cup. Lightly bright and juicy acidity, creamy mouthfeel. The plum-blossom note in particular lingers in a sweet and persistent finish.
p2: Notes: The high mountain valleys of central Papua New Guinea offer some of the world’s most favorable terroirs for production of fine coffee. When these coffees are carefully prepared by the traditional wet or washed method, as is the case with this coffee, they can compete with the worlds finest. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Anyone who enjoys purity without simplicity. Lively, balanced and classic.

coffee_origin: Kona growing region, "Big Island" of Hawaii.
p1: Blind Assessment: Gentle, sweetly tart, delicately complex. Honey, sweet citrus, nut butter, night-blooming flowers in aroma and cup. Soft acidity; leanish but quite silky mouthfeel. Pleasingly rich though rather short finish.
p2: Notes: This Kona coffee was sourced through the original founder of Paradise Coffee, R. Miguel Meza. Miguel has recently established Isla Coffee, a producer and distributor of specialty green coffee primarily from Hawaii and Taiwan. This lot is from the 2012 harvest. Paradise Roasters specializes in micro-lot coffees and espressos from Hawaii and other premier coffee growing regions.  The company prides itself on quality and freshness, craft-roasting coffees in small batches only after orders are placed.  Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Nicely expresses the characteristic soft acidity, sweetness and delicate complexity of the finest Kona coffees.

p1: Blind Assessment: Pungently roasty, crisp. Lightly scorched cedar, dark chocolate, vanilla, brown sugar, a hint of lime zest in aroma and cup. Roast-muted acidity; smooth, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a sweet, mildly drying finish.
p2: Notes: Homlamoon Coffee is a roaster based at Charoenkrung road in Bangkok, Thailand that promises ‘A Pleasure of Coffee’ for their customers.  Visit www.homlamooncoffee.com or call +66-86-316-0911 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a pungently dark-roasted cup that preserves some sweetness and aromatic nuance.

coffee_origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Round, rich, crisply sweet. Minty dark chocolate, night-blooming flowers, fresh-cut cedar, almond in aroma and cup. Gentle acidity; lightly syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a rich though rather drying finish.
p2: Notes: Processed at Buenavista mill, an organic-certified central processing station in Caranavi Province, west-central Bolivia. CaféTaster is an aficionado nano-roaster of the style increasingly characteristic of East Asia countries like Taiwan and Korea, roasting very high-end coffees in very small volumes for a tiny clientele of passionate coffee enthusiasts, in the process selling coffee education as much as coffee itself. For more information, visit www.facebook.com/cafetaster or email roaster Jerry Huang at [email protected]
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a quietly balanced, crisp-finishing chocolate- and floral-toned cup.

coffee_name: Bolivia Caarnavi Buenavista Organic Light Roast
coffee_origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Crisp, richly honey-toned. Honey, prairie flowers, almond, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Gently brisk, delicate acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Rich, balanced, mildly drying finish.
p2: Notes: Processed at Buenavista mill, an organic-certified central processing station in Caranavi Province, west-central Bolivia. Marcheur Roaster is a boutique roastery based in Taipei, Taiwan. The founders, James and Janet, have been importing high-quality green coffees into Taiwan for years and this new roastery represents their further commitment to introducing fine coffees to Taiwanese consumers. Call +886-912545648 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a lighter roasted, delicately brisk, cleanly honey-toned cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, delicate. Caramel, honey, orange zest, a hint of eucalyptus in aroma and cup. Gently tart acidity; light but buoyant mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but persists in a roundly sweet-toned finish.
p2: Notes: Cenfrocafe is a large cooperative in the north of Peru with a total of over two-thousand members. It emphasizes organic growing practices and fair-trade principles, though no certifications appear on this bag. Sunergos Coffee is a three-location, in-store small-batch roasting company with both wholesale and café operations and a complementary interest in both community and quality.  Visit www.sunergoscoffee.com or call 502-634-1243 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: In many respects a classic Peru: soft, buoyant, balanced.

coffee_origin: Carnavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Gentle, balanced, quietly complex. Honey, dark chocolate, pungent fir, orange zest in aroma and cup. Delicate, lively acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet, lightly flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Produced entirely from trees of the Caturra variety, a compact-growing selection of Bourbon, and processed at Buenavista, an organic-certified central processing station in Caranavi Province, west-central Bolivia. The West Bean is a San Diego-based roastery founded by two friends with a passion for coffee and a determination to bring their customers the highest quality hand-crafted coffee possible. The West Bean microroasts only eleven pounds of coffee per batch. Visit www.thewestbean.com or call 619-709-3232 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy delicacy and comfort in a genial medium-roasted cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Intense; richly and crisply bittersweet. Almond, dark chocolate, honey, a hint of flowers and a distinctive tart berry note suggesting, perhaps, acai. Crisp, gently juicy acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. The chocolate note in particular resonates in a long, deep finish.
p2: Notes: Farmer Lucas Vera produced this very small, “nano” lot of fine coffee entirely from trees of the traditional Typica variety of Arabica. Calgary-based Fratello is a second-generation boutique coffee roaster owned by three brothers who focus on responsible trade relationships with coffee growers.  Visit www.fratellocoffee.com or call 800-944-2545 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy naturally crisp, pleasingly bittersweet sensations. This definitely is not the bittersweetness of darker roasted coffees, for example, but is a very graceful bittersweet tartness reminiscent of certain fruits and berries.

coffee_origin: Caranavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet, brisk, zesty. Honey, citrus zest, roasted cocoa nib, honeysuckle in aroma and cup. Crisp, roundly tart acidity; smooth, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Clean, delicately chocolate-toned finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee comes from a direct trade partnership between PT’s Coffee and Juan Yujra, one of the farmers in the Senda Salvaje cooperative, and produced from trees of the Typica and Caturra varieties of Arabica. Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.”  Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a delicately crisp citrus enveloped in honey, floral and cocoa-toned sweetness.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet, pungent, complex. Night-blooming flowers, a sweetness half way between honey and molasses, fresh-cut cedar, grapefruity citrus in aroma and cup. Lively, bright, though balanced acidity; delicate, buoyant mouthfeel. Rich, grapefruity tartness carries into a long, resonant finish.
p2: Notes: Grown, processed and dried on Raul Mamani’s prize-winning five-acre farm near Lake Titicaca on the Peruvian border with Bolivia. Raul is one of 5,325 farmer members of CECOVASA cooperative. Certified organically grown. Based in the San Diego area, Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler focused on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was awarded the “2012 Roaster of the Year” title from Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy pungently sweet, complex beverages with a wide range of sensation, from citrusy tart to floral-toned sweet.

coffee_origin: Carnavi Province, La Paz Department, Bolivia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Deep, opulent, savory-sweet. Crisp roasted nut, minty dark chocolate, hints of butter and sage-like herb in aroma and cup. Rich, deeply expressed acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Long, resonant finish.
p2: Notes: Buenavista is an organic certified central processing station in Caranavi Province, west-central Bolivia. Papa Lin's Coffee Roasting is a very small, “nano” roaster located in Yorktown Heights, New York that features customized roasting profiles for every customer.  Visit www.papalins.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy beverages that combine savory depth with complex sweetness.

p1: Blind Assessment: Pure, powerful, sweetly bright. Chocolate, honey, orange zest, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Richly and roundly tart acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish is tart, resonant and flavor-saturated.
p2: Notes: Wonderstate Coffee has developed a direct relationship with farmers surrounding Huabal village, from whom it buys this impressive coffee via Cenfrocafe, an umbrella cooperative with over two-thousand members. This coffee is certified organic, and although the words "Fair Trade" appear on the label of the attractive valve-topped can, judging by the absence of trademarked seal this coffee may not be certified Fair Trade by FairTrade USA (formerly TransFair USA). However, Wonderstate is affiliated with the Fair Trade Federation, a membership (rather than certifying) organization devoted to "providing fair wages and good employment opportunities to economically disadvantaged artisans and farmers worldwide." Wonderstate Coffee, formerly Kickapoo Coffee, is an award-winning roaster based in rural Wisconsin known for their commitment to guaranteeing higher pay for farmers and being the country’s first 100% solar powered roastery. Visit https://wonderstate.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a classically structured morning cup: bright, big-bodied, but balanced.

coffee_name: Ecuador El Batan Fair Trade Organic
p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet-toned, svelte, refreshing. Honey, lemon, lilac, a hint of roasted cocoa nib in aroma and, more intensely, in the cup. Tartly sweet, lively acidity; velvety, buoyant mouthfeel. Fades just a bit in the long finish, but the short is resonant and flavor-saturated.
p2: Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #25 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. This coffee is from a cooperative of twenty-two farmers clustered near the Ecuador village of El Batan. Equator has extended micro-credits to the cooperative over the last several years and this coming season plans to purchase its entire production. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Equator is a specialty roaster based in the San Francisco Bay Area driven by “passion for quality and sustainability.” Visit www.equatorcoffees.com or call 800-809-7687 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a very pure, balanced lighter-roasted cup, graceful and lyric.

coffee_name: 100 Percent Puna Kazumura Reserve Peaberry Medium Dark
p1: Blind Assessment: Rich, intense, sweetly and pungently citrusy. Melon, grapefruit, sandalwood, musk, caramel in aroma and cup. The acidity is round and pungently tart; the mouthfeel smooth and lightly syrupy. Sweet-toned, flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Puna is the easternmost district of the Big Island of Hawaii, literally on the other side of the island from the far more famous Kona district. From a three-acre farm in Puna owned and operated by Kelleigh Stewart and Brandon von Damitz, who did just about everything related to this coffee, from pruning to roasting. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Visit www.bigislandcoffeeroasters.com or call 808-968-6228 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: This would be a striking and unusual coffee from anywhere in the world, but it is a particular surprise coming from Hawaii, where sweetness and balance are the positive norm rather than the startling aromatic originality of this Puna peaberry.

p1: Blind Assessment: Bittersweet, pungently complex. Night-blooming flowers, crisp chocolate, fresh-cut oak in aroma and cup. Muted, bittersweet acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor carries into a sweet-toned though drying finish.
p2: Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and chocolate cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. Flamenco Organic Coffee, founded in 2005 in Minneapolis, offers one of the country’s largest arrays of Fair-Trade and organic-certified coffees.  Visit www.flamencoorganic.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A crisp, roast-influenced version of the great Gesha profile, with its lush flowers and brisk chocolate.

coffee_name: Guatemala El Injerto Pandora Del Carmen Pacamara
p1: Blind Assessment: Complex, with a savory-sweet depth. Roasted cocoa-nib, jasmine, cedar, honey, orange zest in aroma and cup. Bright, bittersweet acidity; light but very silky mouthfeel. Citrus and floral notes in particular persist in a crisp but resonant finish.
p2: Notes: A special auction lot from El Injerto, one of Guatemala’s most celebrated farms. This lot is comprised entirely of the Pacamara variety, a cross between the giant-beaned Maragogipe variety and Pacas, a selection of the heirloom Bourbon. Paradise Roasters prides itself on roasting and shipping coffee only after orders are placed. Its metaphoric mission is to bring some paradisiacal warmth from the coffee-growing south to the cool environs of Minnesota and beyond.  Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: The particular sensory genius of the Pacamara variety is exhibited well here: savory-sweet depth, crisp cedary chocolate, floral top notes and a slightly bitterish, brightly zesty citrus. The classic crossed with the exotic.

p1: Blind Assessment: Rose-like flowers, honey, sweet chocolate, almond, a hint of fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Delicate, crisply sweet acidity; very smooth, silky mouthfeel. Excellent flavor persistence in a clean, rich finish.
p2: Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and chocolate cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. Coffea Diversa is owned and operated by two brothers who specialize in unique botanical varieties of Arabica. OQ Coffee is a New Jersey-based small-batch roasting company that emphasizes its commitment to coffee quality and community-building. Visit www.oqcoffee.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy purity, elegance and delicate complexity in a lighter-roasted cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Pungent cedar, savory-sweet melon, orange zest, hints of raisin and night-blooming flowers in aroma and cup. Impressively syrupy mouthfeel. A decidedly tart acidity settles down in a very sweet finish.
p2: Notes: JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Tart and savory tendencies balance great sweetness in a structure that supports an intriguingly complex set of aromas and flavors.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweetly balanced and soft with a quiet, tight-knit complexity. Honey, peach, mixed florals (vanilla, jasmine, lavender), nut-butter, orange-toned chocolate in aroma and, more pronounced, in the cup. Gentle acidity; full and silky mouthfeel. The finish is sweet and smooth with a pleasant crispness.
p2: Notes: Produced at around 6,000 feet from trees of the Caturra variety of Arabica. A coffee from Finca Villa Loyola won first place in the 2008 Cup of Excellence competition for Colombia green coffees. Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.”  Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a coffee that is easy-drinking and accessible yet still offers aromatic intrigue.

coffee_origin: Volcan de Santa Ana regioin, El Salvador.
p1: Blind Assessment: Sweetly and pleasantly tart. Honey, orange zest, lily-like flowers, apricot in aroma and cup. Tart, juicy acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. The tart sensation carries into a richly dry finish.
p2: Notes: Finca Malacara was divided into three farms (A, B, and C) in 1955. This lot is comprised in part of the heirloom Bourbon variety. OQ Coffee is a New Jersey-based small-batch roasting company that emphasizes its commitment to coffee quality and community-building. Visit www.oqcoffee.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy complex expressions of richly and sweetly tart sensations in juices and cuisine.

p1: Blind Assessment: Lush, crisply juicy. Lavish, complex floral notes matrixed in ripe, lemony citrus, chocolate, a pungent hint of cedar. Sweetly bright, lively acidity; silky mouthfeel. Long, flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A fine exemplar of the great Yirgacheffe cup, juicy, bright and dramatically aromatic.

p1: Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, quietly complex. Chocolate, night-blooming flowers, vanilla, raspberry-like fruit in aroma and cup. Tart but juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but carries well into a rich, long finish.
p2: Notes: Burundi is a small, landlocked country in Central Africa. Most coffee is grown in the mountains of the north, bordering Rwanda. Benefiting from ideal growing conditions and large plantings of Bourbon and related heirloom varieties of Arabica, Burundi coffee has an excellent reputation and a growing following among North American specialty roasters.JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy Central African tart berry and floral chocolate character in a briskly bright but balanced cup.

coffee_origin: Guji Zone, Sidama Province, southern Ethiopia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet, deep, fermenty. Very ripe blueberry and strawberry, minty dark chocolate, brandy, walnut in aroma and cup. Round, rich acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. A savory edge in the cup turns more prominent in a drying finish.
p2: Notes: This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Flight Coffee Co. (formerly CQ Coffee Roasters) is a coffee-loving, quality-focused roasting company based in Bedford, New Hampshire.Visit www.flightcoffeeco.com or call 603-836-6228 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A massive, robust example of the fruity, brandyish style of Ethiopian dried-in-the-fruit coffee, with a savory weight in cup and finish complicating the usual big, blueberryish sweetness. Those coffee drinkers who know and value Ethiopian dried-in-the-fruit coffee should enjoy this hearty variant.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly and rather tartly bright in aroma and small cup: fresh-cut fir and tangerine-like citrus are rounded by a honey- and chocolate-toned sweetness. Impressively full, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish is tartly bright but smooth. Retains character in two- to four-parts milk with a dry chocolate dominating.
p2: Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #29 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. Decaffeinated by the "Swiss Water Process" method, which does not involve use of solvents. Seattle Coffee Works is a small-batch retail and wholesale roasting company, focused on quality and green coffee sourcing without compromise. Visit www.seattlecoffeeworks.com or call 206-340-8867 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Decaf drinkers who value a bright but richly syrupy espresso with solid presence in milk.

coffee_origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Rich, round: buttery caramel, dark chocolate, night flowers, pungent hints of cedar and date. Crisply sweet acidity; silky to lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The deep-toned floral note in particular surfaces in a flavor-rich though slightly drying finish.
p2: Notes: Certified organically grown by the Fondo Paez Cooperative. Although a logo for "FairTradeProof.org" appears on the label of the attractive 12-ounce valve-topped can, the absence of the trademarked Fair Trade seal indicates this coffee is not certified by Fair Trade USA. Conscious Coffee is, however, affiliated with the buyers' group Cooperative Coffees as well as the Fair Trade Federation, a membership (rather than certifying) organization devoted to "providing fair wages and good employment opportunities to economically disadvantaged artisans and farmers worldwide." Conscious Coffee is a wholesale roasting company focused on organic single-origin coffees and direct trade relationships with growers. It is committed to low impact business practices and "supporting communities, not commodities."  Visit www.consciouscoffees.com or call 800-365-8616 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer a crisp but deep-toned and caramelly breakfast cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Deep, rich, chocolate- and cedar-toned. Gently scorched cedar, plum, chocolate, and a hint of anise in aroma and small cup. Syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate and cedar carry into a sweet but drying finish. Dominates two parts milk, but the fruit-toned chocolate rounds and softens in four parts.
p2: Notes: The Beanery is a Valdosta, Georgia-based wholesale roaster that believes in the old fashioned approach of getting to know its customers with the intent of providing customized service.  Visit www.thebeanery.com or call 229-242-1979 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy rich, chocolaty darker roasted espresso blends. Holds up well in taller milk drinks.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweetly crisp, unusual and striking flavor and aroma. Pecan, chocolate, black-cherry-like fruit in aroma and cup, moist pipe tobacco in aroma. Quiet but lively acidity; silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates and sweetness persists in a balanced finish.
p2: Notes: Certified organically grown and Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning this coffee was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Flores is an island in Indonesia, part of a chain of islands that extends east of Java and Bali. With a recent focus on quality and assistance from international aid groups, Flores is beginning to create a name for itself in specialty coffee circles. Café Virtuoso is a small-batch coffee roaster that strives to procure, roast and deliver the best quality coffee in San Diego. Visit www.cafevirtuoso.com or call 619-550-1830 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Lovers of the more refined style of Sumatras may find this coffee interesting and appealing, as will those who enjoy beverages that combine great natural sweetness with a crisp, dry mouthfeel.

p1: Blind Assessment: Delicate but lush; piercingly sweet. Honey, jasmine-like flowers, tangelo-like citrus, hints of chocolate and fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Lyric, flower-saturated acidity; full but lively mouthfeel. The tangelo note in particular resonates inside immense sweetness in the finish.
p2: Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #9 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. Coffee from trees of the botanical variety "Gesha" or "Geisha" grown on farmer Price Peterson's Hacienda La Esmeralda in Panama has consistently broken records paid for a green coffee. With its long, boat-shaped beans and distinctive floral and chocolate cup, the Esmeralda Panama Gesha continues one of the world's most unique coffees. "Mario" refers to the area of the farm in which the coffee was grown, and "Carnaval" the time of year when this particular lot was harvested, relatively early during February of last year, thus associating it with pre-Lenten Carnaval festivities. This coffee is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Terroir is a microroaster focusing on elite single-origin coffees. It was a pioneer in the revival of medium roast styles designed to foreground the character of the green coffee. Terroir is the creation of George Howell, one of the world's leading coffee visionaries. Visit www.terroircoffee.com or call 866-444-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: The rare and marvelous Gesha at its most characteristic: startlingly distinctive flavor and a complete and flawless structure.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Richly tart yet profoundly sweet. Raspberry-toned dark chocolate, orange or tangerine marmalade, crisp cedar, a hint of flowers in aroma and small cup. Full, buttery mouthfeel. Flavor rounds without losing its complexity or sweetly tart authority in two- to four-parts milk.
p2: Notes: Burundi is a small, landlocked country in Central Africa. Most coffee is grown in the mountains of the north, bordering Rwanda. Benefiting from ideal growing conditions and large plantings of Bourbon and related heirloom varieties of Arabica, Burundi coffee has an excellent reputation and a growing following among North American specialty roasters. This Burundi is specially roasted for espresso brewing. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A superb single-origin espresso, which illustrates how successfully the pleasures of a sweetly bright, high-grown coffee can be deepened but not muted for espresso brewing.

p1: Blind Assessment: Complex, intense, classic. Pungent black currant, blackberry, plum, night-blooming flowers, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Sweetly balanced, lavishly rich acidity. Big, syrupy mouthfeel. The pungent berry notes in particular carry into a deep, long, flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Papa Lin's Coffee Roasting is a very small, “nano” roaster located in Yorktown Heights, New York, that features customized roasting profiles for every customer.  Visit www.papalins.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: In particular, those who enjoy the grand style of Kenya, big, juicy, bright, crisp, but anyone who wants a fine breakfast cup as arresting as it is balanced.

coffee_origin: Gera District of Oromia Region, western Ethiopia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Intensely sweet, complex fruit (marmalade-like orange, plum, blackberry) and flowers (rose, lavender) in aroma and particularly cup. Lushly bright, juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates but sustains in a long, deep finish.
p2: Notes: Produced by small-holding members of the Yukro Cooperative at high growing elevations from indigenous heirloom varieties of Arabica. Terroir is a microroaster focusing on elite single-origin coffees. It was a pioneer in the revival of medium roast styles designed to foreground the character of the green coffee. Terroir is the creation of George Howell, one of the world's leading coffee visionaries. Visit www.georgehowellcoffee.com or call 866-444-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who value intensity and excitement in flavor and sweet-toned, juicy acidity.

coffee_origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southwestern Colombia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Gently bright, sweetly crisp. Fresh-cut fir, almond, honeysuckle-like flowers, lemon curd in aroma and cup. Delicate, soft acidity; silky mouthfeel. Surprisingly rich, resonant finish.
p2: Notes: Paradise Roasters prides itself on roasting and shipping coffee only after orders are placed. Its metaphoric mission is to bring some paradisiacal warmth from the coffee-growing south to the cool environs of Minnesota and beyond. Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who value pure, delicately classic breakfast coffees. Don’t even think about putting whitener in this one.

p1: Blind Assessment: Crisply but lushly sweet and fruit-toned. Narcissus-like flowers, blueberry, cidery peach, roasted cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Softly crisp acidity; full, lively mouthfeel. The floral and blueberry notes carry into a gently drying, bittersweet finish.
p2: Notes: This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Papa Lin's Coffee Roasting is a very small, “nano” roaster located in Yorktown Heights, New York, that features customized roasting profiles for every customer.  Visit www.papalins.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Nice balance of lush, slightly fermenty fruit and floral sweetness with a gently drying briskness should please those who enjoy such juxtapositions in ales and whiskies, for example, or good port wines.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Pungent, deep, richly tart. Dark chocolate, apricot, roasted nut, orangy cedar in aroma and small cup. Full, syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a resonant finish. Dominates two parts milk; perhaps shows best in four parts or taller milk, which rounds the tart pungency and better develops the sweetness in the chocolate.
p2: Notes: Burundi is a small, landlocked country in Central Africa. Most coffee is grown in the mountains of the north, bordering Rwanda. Benefiting from ideal growing conditions and large plantings of Bourbon and related heirloom varieties of Arabica, Burundi coffee has an excellent reputation and a growing following among North American specialty roasters. This Burundi is specially roasted for espresso brewing. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a deeply and richly tart straight shot or an authoritative coffee component in taller milk drinks.

p1: Blind Assessment: Quiet, sweetly crisp. Honey, milk chocolate, nut, a hint of night-blooming flowers in aroma and cup. Soft, gently juicy acidity; balanced mouthfeel. Nut and chocolate carry into a sweet-toned finish.
p2: Notes: Produced from trees of the heirloom Bourbon and the Caturra and Pache varieties of Arabica by the indigenous Mayan members of the Tzampetey Cooperative. Terroir is a microroaster focusing on elite single-origin coffees. It was a pioneer in the revival of medium roast styles designed to foreground the character of the green coffee. Terroir is the creation of George Howell, one of the world's leading coffee visionaries. Visit www.georgehowellcoffee.com or call 866-444-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer a round, quietly complex cup, comfortable with a hint of the exotic.

p1: Blind Assessment: Intricate, richly pungent: chocolate fudge, spicy oak, wild berry, faint mango-like fruit and night-blooming flowers in aroma and cup. Soft, sweetly tart acidity; full velvety mouthfeel. The finish is berry-toned, with a rounded chocolaty sweetness.
p2: Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #27 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. Maragogipe (Maragojipe in Spanish; also spelled Maragogype) is a variety of Arabica first discovered growing near the Brazilian town of the same name. It is a seldom-grown variety that produces enormous beans. Klatch Coffee is an award-winning small-batch roasting company in the Los Angeles area whose resident barista and trainer, Heather Perry, won both the 2003 and 2007 United States Barista Championships brewing a Klatch Coffee espresso blend. Visit www.klatchroasting.com or call 877-455-2824 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Usually the rare Maragogipe wows us with its giant beans but disappoints in the cup. This lot, however, displays an interesting and impressive sensory profile, making it an appealing buy both for the coffee curious and those simply interested in a satisfying and unusual cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Deep, rich, resonantly low-toned. Minty chocolate, agave syrup, dried fig, a hint of rose-like flowers in aroma and cup. Round, quiet acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate and fig in particular carry into a long finish.
p2: Notes: Rwanda's potential as fine coffee producer has only come to fruition over the past several years owing to generous support from international aid agencies, the specialty coffee community and the industry of its growers. Produced entirely from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety. Big Creek Coffee Roasters is a small, quality-oriented batch roaster located in Montana’s Bitterroot Valley. Visit www.bigcreekcoffeeroasters.com or call 406-375-7508 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: The style of coffee we used to call “after-dinner,” though its resonant richness, quiet complexity and roast-moderated acidity should please any time of day.

coffee_name: Harfusa Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Fair Trade Organic
p1: Blind Assessment: Complex but harmonious. Honey and a very sweet citrus suggesting candied lemon dominate in aroma and cup, with complications of almond, fresh-cut fir and a soft caramel. Smoothly and sweetly tart acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Deep, flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company.Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Smoothly tart and lushly sweet, surprisingly full in mouthfeel, deeply nuanced in aroma and flavor, this is a morning cup that both expresses and transcends classic.

coffee_origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Immense, resonant, shifting aroma and flavor. Rose- and lavender-like flowers, cantaloupe, peppercorn, dark chocolate, rye whisky just as starters. Functional, integrated acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Long, rich, flavor saturated finish with a dry, savory edge.
p2: Notes: This exceptional coffee was selected as the #21 coffee in the Coffee Review Top 30 Coffees of 2013. This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with “wet-hulled” coffees more typical of northern Sumatra. Wahana Estate is a relatively new coffee farm in the classic Lintong growing district near Lake Toba. Bard Coffee is a coffeehouse and roasting company based in Portland, Maine, focused on distinctive single-origin coffees. Bard Coffee is co-owned by Bob Garver, founder of Wicked Joe coffee and a frequent judge at barista competitions in the United States and internationally. Visit www.bardcoffee.com or call 207-899-4788 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A light but fully developed roast encourages expression of a massive and ultimately harmonious complexity that should surprise and please any coffee drinker save the most conventional in taste.

p1: Blind Assessment: Delicate, pure, balanced. Honey, flowers, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Gentle, juicy acidity; smooth, lively, almost effervescent mouthfeel. A hint of chocolate surfaces in a sweet finish.
p2: Notes: Produced from trees of the Caturra variety, a compact-growing selection of Bourbon, from Las Hermosa farm and surrounding El Eden hamlets. Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees through the roasting process all the way to the cup.  Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Lovers of very pure, delicately balanced beverages.

p1: Blind Assessment: Hazelnut and a tangerine-like citrus are enveloped in a milk chocolate sweetness in aroma and cup. Crisp, delicate acidity; light but very smoothly silky mouthfeel. Sweet, rich, though rather drying in the finish.
p2: Notes: The Antigua Valley produces some of Central America’s most traditional and classic coffees. Mystic Monk Coffee is a small-batch roaster associated with a Carmelite monastery located in the Rocky Mountains of northern Wyoming. Roastmaster Brother Java emphasizes his artisan approach to roasting and his commitment to quality.  Visit www.mysticmonkcoffee.com or call 877-751-6377 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a crisply sweet, suavely nuanced breakfast cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Reviewed as espresso. Tart, raspberry-like fruit balanced by a dark chocolate and almond sweetness in aroma and small cup. Gently syrupy mouthfeel; crisply chocolaty finish. In two parts milk the tart fruit character turns rich and deep, supported by a chocolate predictably milk-sweetened.
p2: Notes: Caldi Coffee is a small coffeehouse located in Tao-yuan City, Taiwan that devotes itself to providing “splendid coffee” at affordable prices.  Visit http://www.caldicafe.url.tw/caldi/module.php or call +886-3-3364965 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: The tart raspberry-like fruit is attractive in the straight shot and particularly impressive in short milk.

p1: Blind Assessment: Bright, sweetly tart. Orange zest and fresh-cut fir softened by a backgrounded dark chocolate and molasses in aroma and cup. A hint of jasmine. Lightly syrupy mouthfeel; crisp, flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees through the roasting process all the way to the cup.  Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a classic, straightforward breakfast cup, sweetly bright but not sharp.

coffee_name: Cosecha de Oro Colombia Light Roast
p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet-toned, balanced, quiet. Fresh-cut, aromatic cedar dominates, with hints of orange, milk chocolate and lily-like flowers in the aroma and more prominently in the cup. Round, gentle acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate persists in a sweet though rather short finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee is 100% Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee.  Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy gentle medium-roasted blends with soft acidity and quiet, layered flavor and aromatics.

p1: Blind Assessment: Straightforward, muted, sweet. Caramel, candied pecan, fresh alfalfa, a hint of orange zest in aroma and cup. Round, quiet acidity; smooth, lightly creamy mouthfeel. Clean, crisply sweet finish.
p2: Notes: Decaffeinated without the use of solvents. Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees through the roasting process all the way to the cup.  Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Decaf drinkers will find some pleasures here, including smooth, pleasing mouthfeel and a nut-toned, caramelly sweetness.

coffee_origin: Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; Cerrado growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.
p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Buttery dark chocolate and hints of flowers, vanilla and cedar in the roundly balanced aroma. In the small cup the cedar comes forward and the chocolate turns crisp and backgrounded. Medium, lightly syrupy mouthfeel; gently and richly drying finish with good persistence of the chocolate note. Crisp and balanced in two parts milk crisp, with excellent flavor persistence: The buttery chocolate dominates with the cedar note once again backgrounded.
p2: Notes: Creation Food is a food service company with a specialty coffee division. It operates one of the few large-scale coffee production facilities in Taiwan.  Visit www.creation.com.tw  or call 0800-020-368  for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Versatile espresso; crisply chocolaty both as straight shot and in short milk.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Dark chocolate, cedar, roasted nut, vanilla, blackberry in the impressive aroma. The aromatics dry out a bit in the small cup but retain complexity; the mouthfeel is full and robust; the finish richly drying with some flavor persistence. In two parts milk the coffee rather sharply dominates the milk, but it softens and blooms while retaining some complexity in four parts.
p2: Notes: Creation Food is a food service company with a specialty coffee division. It operates one of the few large-scale coffee production facilities in Taiwan.  Visit www.creation.com.tw  or call 0800-020-368  for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a brisk, complex straight shot.

coffee_origin: Antigua growing region, Guatemala; Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; Mandheling growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. In the aroma tart plum, soft cedar, backgrounded chocolate and floral hints. In the small cup a tart character dominates, turning the flowers toward anise and suppressing the chocolate. Lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Chocolate resurfaces in the crisply sweet finish. Flavor carries nicely into two parts milk, which rounds without suppressing the tart fruit while predictably intensifying the chocolate.
p2: Notes: Creation Food is a food service company with a specialty coffee division. It operates one of the few large-scale coffee production facilities in Taiwan.  Visit www.creation.com.tw  or call 0800-020-368  for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Tart but smooth straight shot blooms nicely in short milk.

coffee_name: Bluekoff Single Origin Thai Espresso Blend (A4+A5)
p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Sweet-toned aroma: Banana, crème de menthe, dark chocolate, ripe plum. In the small cup creamy mouthfeel with rich depth and balance; the chocolate turns caramelly and the fruit richer and sweeter, complicated by a hint of anise. Flavor persists in a resonant finish. Excellent flavor in two parts milk: dark chocolate, plum, mint.
p2: Notes: The A in this blends name refers to the grade of the coffee purchased, and the 4 and 5 reference two different roast profiles blended together. Bluekoff is a company in Thailand that involved in all aspects of coffee, from milling and roasting to coffee wholesale and retail and related equipment and training services. Visit www.bluekoff.com or call +66-81-751-1217 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Impressive straight-shot espresso, with buttery body and sweet depth, but perhaps at its best in short milk, where it retains its richness and individuality.

coffee_name: Doi Chaang Wild Civet Passed Coffee
p1: Blind Assessment: Originally cupped in November 2010.  Balanced, smoothly complete coffee: the raisiny fruit and cedary dark chocolate in the aroma sweetens toward fresh cherry and milk chocolate in the cup, with a tart complication of lemon. Sweetly tart, citrus-toned acidity; very smooth, silky mouthfeel. Flavor simplifies a bit in the clean finish.
p2: Notes: Doi Chaang is a single-estate coffee produced by a northern Thailand hill tribe in the Golden Triangle mountains of Thailand and roasted in Alberta, Canada. The independent coffee growers receive over 50% of the profits of this unusual and pioneering venture. In addition to its excellent conventional arabica coffees, the cooperative members harvest small quantities of two versions of the famous (or infamous) kopi luwak, the world’s most expensive coffee, the beans of which are “processed” by a species of wild civet that eats ripe coffee fruit. The version reviewed here is comprised of beans that they have swallowed along with the fruit, and which are harvested from their feces. Visit www.doichaangcoffee.com or call 866-924-2264 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: The provocative processing method via a mammal’s digestive tract produces a quietly notable coffee here, though more remarkable for classic balance than exotic strangeness. The combination of tart lemon and raisiny chocolate is a bit unusual in the sensory world of coffee, however, and here quite attractive.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Deep, sweet-toned aroma: dark chocolate, butter, leather, a hint of pineapple. In the small cup the pineapply fruit note moves forward and dry anise and cedar notes complicate the sweet chocolate. The buttery smoothness of the aroma reasserts itself in a very persistent, complex finish. Rather light, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Very fine in three parts milk: buttery chocolate, pineapply fruit, richly balance.
p2: Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. This Kenya is specially roasted for espresso brewing. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: An engagingly aromatic and complex straight shot that develops with balance and rich nuance in cappuccino-sized milk.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet, lyrical, meadowy. Honey, meadow flowers, richly pungent moist pipe tobacco, a hint of toffee in aroma and in cup, where the flowers deepen and sweeten toward an opulent honeysuckle. Delicate but lushly soft acidity; lightly silky mouthfeel. Very rich, honeyish finish with a savory hint.
p2: Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Beansmith Coffee is a small-batch roasting company serving the Omaha region that believes that coffee drinkers should know as much as they can about the coffee they drink, and that there is a story behind every cup, one worth exploring.  Visit www.beansmith.com or call 866-663-5295 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: The cushiony, plush acidity and floral sweetness makes this an accessible and inviting version of the great Kenya profile.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart, richly dry. Blackberry and black currant notes dominate in aroma and cup, supported by hints of flowers, honey and cedar. Round, complexly expressed acidity; very smooth, silky mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a sweet-toned, resonant finish.
p2: Notes: Produced by the Ruthaka FCS Cooperative from trees of the admired, Bourbon-derived SL 28 variety of Arabica as well as the hybrid Ruiru 11 variety. Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. AA is the highest grade of Kenya coffee based on bean size and freedom from physical imperfections. Victrola is a small-batch, hands-on roaster with a passionate commitment to quality and distinctiveness. Visit www.victrolacoffee.com or call 206-624-1725 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Classic Kenya richly displays all the pleasures of the type: big but rounded acidity; elegantly complex, sweetly tart berry notes; silky mouthfeel.

coffee_origin: Karatina district, Nyeri growing region, Kenya.
p1: Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart, complexly floral. Honey, honeysuckle, lavender, hints of barley and fir in aroma and cup. Soft but brisk acidity; light but very silky mouthfeel. The finish is flavor-saturated and quite rich and deep for such a delicate coffee.
p2: Notes: This coffee was produced exclusively from trees of Kenya’s premier varieties of Arabica, the great, Bourbon-related SL 28 and SL 34. Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. This particular Kenya is produced by members of the Mugaga Cooperative Society at an elevation of approximately 5,000 feet. Klatch Coffee is an award-winning small-batch roasting company in the Los Angeles area whose resident barista and trainer, Heather Perry, won both the 2003 and 2007 United States Barista Championships brewing a Klatch Coffee espresso blend.  Visit www.klatchroasting.com or call 877-455-2824 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Anyone who enjoys a briskly sweet morning cup; the particularly complex floral notes range from bitter and hoppy to lushly honeyish.

p1: Blind Assessment: Great range of aromatic and flavor sensation. Bright, sweet-toned and floral, but with molasses, mushroom, moist wood and rich musk notes deepening and complicating the profile. Delicate, brisk acidity; smoothly silky mouthfeel. Drying but sweet, mushroom-toned finish.
p2: Notes: A version of the famous Kopi Luwak, the world's most notorious coffee. The beans are harvested from the feces of a species of civet cat, in this case a species resident in the Philippines, that eats ripe coffee fruit. Faustino Coffee Company is an Ontario, California based importer and distributer of coffees from the company’s estates in the Philippines.  Visit www.faustinoco.com or call 951-205-2383 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: One of the best luwaked coffees we have sampled over the past few years, with genuinely unique aromatics. Only you can decide whether those unique aromatics are worth the high price.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. In the straight shot complex floral notes ranging from lavender to lily, honey, fresh-cut cedar, vanilla-toned dark chocolate. The mouthfeel is medium in weight and lightly syrupy in texture; the finish sweet and resonantly persistent. Preserves character in two parts milk with a zesty orange-toned chocolate and a continuing hint of flowers.
p2: Notes: In addition to his retail roasting operation Aroma Roast Coffees, Simon Hsieh also operates Soaring Phoenix Trading, a business focused on purposed-built commercial espresso blends and high quality single-origin coffees. Visit www.facebook.com/4ArtsZeroDefectCoffees or call 886-0983-749876 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy distinctive single-origin profiles that have been rounded and deepened but not tamed for use in espresso applications. Maintains individuality even in short milk.

coffee_name: Brazil Pocos de Caldas S.O. Espresso
p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. In the small cup complex aroma and flavor: dark chocolate, honey, night-florals, grape-like fruit, pungent cedar. Impressively syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor consolidates in a sweet though drying finish. Balanced and rather brisk in two parts milk: chocolate, cedar, flowers.
p2: Notes: Processed by the traditional Brazilian natural or dry method, meaning the coffee was dried with both skin and fruit still adhering to the beans. Produced entirely from trees of the heirloom Yellow Bourbon variety of Arabica. Paradise Roasters prides itself on roasting and shipping coffee only after orders are placed. Its metaphoric mission is to bring some paradisiacal warmth from the coffee-growing south to the cool environs of Minnesota and beyond.  Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Impressive complexity and depth of sensation in a single-origin espresso.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Soft, lush aroma: molasses, lilac-like flowers, chocolate crème. In the small cup full, syrupy mouthfeel and continued molasses, flowers and chocolate with a deep, black-cherry-like fruit. Sweet, chocolate-toned finish. Flavor loses some of its depth and intrigue in two parts milk, though the chocolate survives.
p2: Notes: Elicsire Ltd is a producer of EBENICA Coffee located in the Slovak Republic pursuing the goal of bringing a gourmet coffee experience to Slovakia and beyond through the use of high-quality coffee.  Visit www.ebenica.com  or call +421-917-853-555 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Deep and quietly complex, particularly as a straight shot.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Crisp, lavender-like flowers, molasses sweetness, dark chocolate in aroma and small cup. Creamy mouthfeel. Flavor carries into a smooth finish. The chocolate sweetens and rounds but maintains a crisp complication of lavender in two parts milk.
