p1: Blind Assessment: Lushly bright and complex. Almond, orange, fresh-cut cedar; hints of chocolate, honey and night-blooming flowers in aroma and cup. Big, sweet-toned acidity; lively, syrupy mouthfeel. Resonantly flavor saturated, gently drying finish.
p2: Notes: Processed by the classic wet or “washed” method: fruit is removed before drying using traditional ferment-and-wash methods and the beans are sun-dried. Produced on Finca La Bolsa from trees of the Bourbon and Caturra varieties of Arabica. Beansmith Coffee is a small-batch roasting company located in La Vista, Nebraska that believes that coffee drinkers should know as much as they can about the coffee they drink, and that there is a story behind every cup, one worth exploring.  Visit www.beansmith.com or call 866-663-5295 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Classic Guatemalan variation on the classic American breakfast cup: sweetly acidy, big-bodied, complex, rich.

p1: Blind Assessment: Exhilaratingly bittersweet and complex. Floral notes ranging from sweet and vanilla to crisp lavender, roasted cocoa nib, orange zest in aroma and cup. Crisp, floral-toned acidity; light but lively, silky mouthfeel. Floral notes in particular carry into a drying but sweet-toned finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Processed by the classic wet or “washed” method: fruit is removed before drying using traditional ferment-and-wash methods and the beans are sun-dried. Konga is a Zone in the celebrated Yirgacheffe growing region of southern Ethiopia. Café Virtuoso is a small-batch coffee roaster that strives to procure, roast and deliver the best quality coffee in San Diego. Visit www.cafevirtuoso.com or call 619-550-1830 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A brisk, rather elegant bittersweet character makes this an unusual variation on the great Yirgacheffe profile.

coffee_name: Mexico Chiapas Phoenix Special S.O. Espresso
p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Rich, deep, nutty. Molasses, roasted pecan, dark chocolate and pungent, pineapple-like fruit in aroma and small cup. Fullish, creamy mouthfeel; richly dry, fruit-toned finish. Fruit and chocolate survive, though quietly, in two parts milk.
p2: Notes: In addition to his retail roasting operation Aroma Roast Coffees, Simon Hsieh also operates Soaring Phoenix Trading, a business focused on purposed-built commercial espresso blends and high quality single-origin coffees. Visit www.facebook.com/4ArtsZeroDefectCoffees or call 886-0983-749876 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Impressive aromatic range and complexity with pleasing mouthfeel in the straight shot; fades a bit in milk.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Deep, earthy, savory. Dark chocolate, caramel, nut, rich earth and faint orange- and apricot-toned fruit in aroma and small cup. Round, lightly syrupy mouthfeel; a crisply dry chocolate dominates in a flavor-saturated finish and carries persuasively into two-parts milk with a complicating hint of orangy fruit.
p2: Notes: CofFeeling is a one-location roaster-café situated adjacent to of one of Taiwan’s most elegantly designed metro stations. Visit www.coffeelingcafe.com or call +886-7-285-5300 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy depth and savory sweetness in a versatile espresso.

p1: Blind Assessment: Crisp, complex. Almond, caramel, spicy flowers, tart berry, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Brisk, bittersweet acidity; light but silky mouthfeel. Hints of chocolate and flowers carry into a gently drying finish.
p2: Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. AA is the highest grade of Kenya coffee based on bean size and freedom from physical imperfections. GreenAlives is a Taiwan small-batch roasting company located in the Xin-Zhuang District of New Taipei City that pursues quality in every act of coffee production from green coffee selection through storage, roasting and educating customers in optimum brewing practice.  Visit www.greenalives.com or call +886-0921-884-579 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy dry, spicy, floral-toned white table wines.

coffee_origin: Mattari growing region Yemen; Yirgacheffe growing region, southern Ethiopia; Mandheling growing region, Sumatra, Indonesia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Rich, low-toned, savory. Walnut, salty dark chocolate, caramel and a hint of flowers in aroma and cup. Round, muted acidity; full, slightly rough mouthfeel. Chocolate in particular lingers in a long finish.
p2: Notes: Mocha-Java is the world’s earliest blend. It combined the only two coffees available in the world in the 17th century: “Mocha” from Yemen and Java from the Dutch colony in what is now Indonesia. This version combines the traditional Yemen with a Sumatra in place of the Java plus a third coffee from the Yirgacheffe region of Ethiopia. GreenAlives is a Taiwan small-batch roasting company located in the Xin-Zhuang District of New Taipei City that pursues quality in every act of coffee production from green coffee selection through storage, roasting and educating customers in optimum brewing practice.  Visit www.greenalives.com or call +886-0921-884-579 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy rich, savory-sweet beverages. Should take whitener well.

p1: Blind Assessment: Crisply sweet, quietly but profoundly complex. Honey, lavender-like flowers, roasted cocoa nib, ripe orange and guava in aroma and cup. Sweet, lively acidity; light but silky mouthfeel. Long, resonant, deeply flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and chocolate cup, the Geisha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. This particular Gesha is produced on the Ninety Plus Gesha Estates. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast.  Visit www.barringtoncoffee.com or call 800-528-0998 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Giddily sweet and complex expression of the Gesha cup. If you can afford it, try it.

coffee_origin: Lintong growing region, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Deep, earthy, savory. Fresh-turned earth, dark chocolate, clove-like spice, hints of highland Scotch whisky in aroma and cup. The acidity is integrated and saturated with flavor; the mouthfeel medium in weight and smooth in texture; the finish richly complex.
p2: Notes: Coffees from the northern part of the Indonesian island of Sumatra are admired for their complex earth, fruit and aromatic wood notes that result largely from unorthodox fruit removal and drying practices called “wet hulling.” This coffee is a particularly intense and particularly refined example of the type. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale specialty roaster active in Sacramento, California since 2005. Committed to sourcing, roasting and brewing the finest coffees, Temple features coffee from distinguished single estates and cooperatives around the world.  Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A superb, unapologetic Sumatra of the deep, cleanly and richly earthy style.

coffee_name: El Salvador Los Pirineos Natural Red Bourbon
p1: Blind Assessment: Heady brandy-like notes, complex fruit and crisp baker’s chocolate in aroma and cup. Balanced, gently juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The chocolate note in particular carries into a quietly rich finish.
p2: Notes: This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. It was produced from trees of the red-fruited form of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. Calgary-based Fratello is a second-generation boutique coffee roaster owned by three brothers who focus on responsible trade relationships with coffee growers.  Visit www.fratellocoffee.com or call 800-944-2545 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Exotic, richly brandy-toned cup for coffee adventurers.

p1: Blind Assessment: Rich, close-knit complexity. Flowers, honey, lime, nut-toned dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Balanced, juicy acidity; lively, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Gently flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: This lot is comprised of beans from the traditional Typica and the heirloom Bourbon varieties of Arabica. Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees through the roasting process and all the way to the cup.  Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Classic Central American breakfast cup: balanced, juicy, complete.

p1: Blind Assessment: Deep, pungent. Molasses, walnut, buttery dark chocolate, lush night flowers in aroma and cup. Brisk but integrated acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet though drying finish.
p2: Notes: Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees through the roasting process and all the way to the cup.  Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who prefer red wines and whisky to white wines and vodka.

coffee_origin: La Paz District, Marcala growing region, Honduras.
p1: Blind Assessment: Gently pungent, harmoniously complex. Sweet flowers, rich, cocoa-like chocolate, walnut and an orangy fruit in aroma and cup. Crisp acidity. Delicate, very silky mouthfeel. Flavor persists into a rather drying finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee represents a micro-lot project, Lot 36, from an eight-acre parcel within the eighty-three acre Finca Las Esmeraldas farm. Barrington Coffee is an artisan roaster dedicated to elite coffees, fresh delivery and roasting that foregrounds the coffee and not the roast.  Visit www.barringtoncoffee.com or call 800-528-0998 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Lovers of crisply complex, dry white table wines.

p1: Blind Assessment: Flat and woody with a cloying, disturbing sweetness and not much else in way of flavor or aroma. The sweetness could be taken as slightly composty or slightly chocolaty or both. Virtually no acidity; smooth but leanish mouthfeel. The composty sweetness is most intense and unpleasant in the cup, less so in the finish.
p2: Notes: Purchased in pre-ground format at Costco in San Leandro, California for an equivalent of $3.66 per pound. Folgers is a 160-year old coffee brand founded in San Francisco, acquired in 1963 by Procter & Gamble, and sold in 2008 to the J.M. Smucker Company.  Visit www.folgers.com or call 800-937-9745 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Very low price; very, very poor quality by any standard that we know of.

p1: Blind Assessment: Decent structure: tartly brisk, though bitterish acidity, light but silky mouthfeel. Aroma and flavor are muted and mildly unpleasant, however: Faint, faded cedar, overripe fruit that with imagination hints at chocolate. The fruit turns sourish in the finish.
p2: Notes: Purchased in whole bean format at Walmart in San Leandro, California at an equivalent of $7.24 per pound. Eight O'Clock coffee originated with the A&P supermarket chain in 1919, and is one of America's most long-lived and traditional coffee brands, offering whole-bean, all-Arabica coffee in retro-looking bags at prices that come close to competing with cheap, Robusta-heavy canned blends. In 2005 Eight O'Clock was acquired by Tata Coffee, a vertically integrated Indian coffee growing, exporting, roasting and retailing company.  Visit www.eightoclock.com or call 800-299-2739 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: We’ve tasted this brand and this coffee when it was considerably better. Maybe you’ll get lucky with yours.

p1: Blind Assessment: Clean, simple, woody. Sweet, mildly charred wood, molasses, caramel in aroma and cup. Soft, muted acidity; medium body, slightly lean mouthfeel. Muted flavor fades quickly in a clean but drying finish.
p2: Notes: Purchased in pre-ground format at Walmart in San Leandro, California at an equivalent of $5.21 per pound. Great Value is a proprietary brand of Walmart, the world's largest retailer.  Visit www.walmart.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Nothing wrong; nothing much right here either except for the very attractive price. A clean but very simple, woody cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet-toned, clean, neutral. Grainy sweetness, faint nut and chocolate hints in aroma and cup. Delicately brisk, muted acidity. Fullish though rather inert mouthfeel. Some chocolaty sweetness persists in a clean though rather empty finish.
p2: Notes: Purchased in whole bean format at Costco in San Leandro, California for an equivalent of $5.99 per pound. With this, one of four “Blonde” or medium-roasted blends, Starbucks breaks with its long commitment to dark-roasting. This blend, described as “Mellow & Soft,” is apparently aimed at those who prefer a brisker, more delicate cup than presented by any of Starbucks’ usual offerings.  Visit www.starbucks.com or call 800-782-7282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those looking for Starbucks’ version of “mellow and soft” (very) at an attractive price.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet-toned and balanced, though muted. Fresh-cut fir, chocolate, caramel, perhaps an apricot-like fruit, all rather subdued, in aroma and cup. Soft, faintly brisk acidity; leanish but smooth mouthfeel. Flavor fades quickly in a clean, mildly drying finish.
p2: Notes: Purchased in whole bean format at Walmart in San Leandro, California at an equivalent of $7.31 per pound. This coffee is 100% Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Sam’s Choice is a proprietary brand of Walmart, the world's largest retailer.  Visit www.walmart.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a cleanly delicate medium roast at a reasonable price.

p1: Blind Assessment: Dark chocolate, brandy, blueberry, fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Backgrounded but functional acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Rich but simple, drying finish.
p2: Notes: A “natural” or dry-processed coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is lower-toned and more pungent than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned southern Ethiopia profile. Certified organically grown, this coffee is processed with great care by Ethiopia's only female coffee mill owner, Asnakech Thomas, who pays high prices for ripe cherry from smallholders in Ethiopia's Amaro region. Vertigo Coffee is a small-batch roaster with a retail café located in picturesque San Juan Batista, California.  Visit www.vertigocoffee.com or call 831-623-9533 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A cigar-and-leather-armchair style coffee, deep and richly brandy-like.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweetly tart and exhilaratingly complex. Richly tart fruit – guava, passion fruit – dominate, rounded by a cocoaish chocolate and lush night blooming flowers. Crisp, juicy acidity; light but very silky, lively mouthfeel. Resonantly flavor-saturated, slightly drying finish.
p2: Notes: Produced mainly from trees of the admired, Bourbon-derived SL28 and SL34 varieties of Arabica. Grown by farmers of the Gitwe cooperative, which operates two wet mills, Karatu and Kariuga, and is composed of 1,868 farmer members. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Classic Kenya: intense, elegant, complex.

p1: Blind Assessment: Striking savory sweet character. Preserved fruit – prune and apricot – walnut and malt in aroma and cup. Gently tart, dry acidity; smooth, rather lean mouthfeel. Chocolate, which showed up in the aroma before losing itself in the cup, resurfaces in a rich, rather sweet-toned finish.
p2: Notes: This lot is comprised entirely of the admired Pacamara variety of Arabica, a cross between the giant-beaned Maragogipe and Pacas, a selection of the heirloom Bourbon. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Unusual coffee, perhaps more distinguished than our rating suggests. Those who value dry, savory undercurrents in beverages – in aged tequilas and cachaças, to give just two examples – should particularly enjoy this coffee.

p1: Blind Assessment: Crisp, sweetly pungent, elegant. Guava, citrus, backgrounded caramel and dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Rich, active, juicy acidity; syrupy but lively mouthfeel. Very sweet, long, flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: From trees of the classic Bourbon-derived Kenya cultivars SL28 and SL34. Terroir is a microroaster focusing on elite single-origin coffees. It was a pioneer in the revival of medium roast styles designed to foreground the character of the green coffee. Terroir is the creation of George Howell, one of the world's leading coffee visionaries. Visit www.terroircoffee.com or call 866-444-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: The celebrated Kenya dry berry character, aka “black currant,” for us displayed here as sweetly tangy, juicy guava. Everything works in this superbly complete, graceful coffee, simultaneously simple and complex, altogether classic.

p1: Blind Assessment: Very sweet, ripe lemon dominates aroma and cup, with prune, fig and molasses complications. Bright, assertive acidity; lightly syrupy, buoyantly lively mouthfeel. The lemon carries deep into a long, resonant finish.
p2: Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctive coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp are removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. Paradise Roasters prides itself on roasting and shipping coffee only after orders are placed. Its metaphoric mission is to bring some paradisiacal warmth from the coffee-growing south to the cool environs of Minnesota and beyond.  Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who find typical Yirgacheffes too light-bodied and floral may particularly enjoy this variant on the type, with its fuller mouthfeel and emphasis on lemon and deeper fig-molasses notes.

coffee_name: Organic Costa Rica Helsar Finca Santa Lucia
p1: Blind Assessment: Delicately complex, crisp. Milk chocolate, raspberry-like fruit, a hint of night-blooming flowers in aroma and cup. Brisk, softly tart acidity; silky mouthfeel. Sweet, juicy, resonant finish.
p2: Notes: Certified organically grown. Finca Santa Lucia is a fifteen-acre coffee farm located in the Valle Central (Central Valley) region of Costa Rica. Paradise Roasters prides itself on roasting and shipping coffee only after orders are placed. Its metaphoric mission is to bring some paradisiacal warmth from the coffee-growing south to the cool environs of Minnesota and beyond.  Visit www.paradiseroasters.com or call 763-433-0626 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Delicate, lively, silky cup should please palates tuned to subtlety.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet, delicately crisp. Dark chocolate, brown sugar, hints of plum and fresh-cut cedar in aroma and cup. Tartly juicy acidity; the mouthfeel is light, hinting at silkiness. Chocolate carries into a gently drying finish.
p2: Notes: Certified organically grown and Fair Trade or “Fair for Life” certified by the Institute for Market-Ecology (IMO), a different certifying body from the more familiar Fair Trade USA certification, deploying parallel but somewhat different criteria and methods. Grounds for Change is a certified organic coffee roaster specializing in sustainable coffee and supporting a wide range of progressive ecological and social programs. The complete carbon footprint (from crop to cup) for this coffee has been offset with tree planting (carbonfund.org). Visit www.groundsforchange.com or call 800-796-6820 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A balanced, quietly complex cup with thorough-going socially and environmentally progressive credentials.

p1: Blind Assessment: Subtle, deep, complex. Night-blooming flowers, red grape, coconut, roasted cocoa nibs, a hint of fir in aroma and cup. Very rich, round acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor carries deep into a resonant finish.
p2: Notes: Produced from trees of the admired, Bourbon-derived SL 28 and SL 34 varieties of Arabica as well as the hybrid Ruiru 11 variety. Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.” Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Aficionados or anyone interested in a particularly deep, pungently lush variation on the classic Kenya cup.

coffee_origin: Kefa (Kaffa) Province, Oromia region, southwestern Ethiopia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Delicate but intense. Flowers, lime, fir and a hint of roasted cocoa nib in the nose. In the cup the flowers and cocoa are backgrounded and a very complex expression of the citrus dominates: ripe lime and grapefruit in particular. Gently tart acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. Sweet, crisply flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Kefa (also spelled Kaffa) is reputed to be the botanical birthplace of Coffea arabica, the species that until the 20th century produced all of the world's commercially traded coffees and still produces all of the great ones. Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.”  Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Sweet, intense Ethiopia with classic citrus and flowers.

p1: Blind Assessment: Crisp, nut-toned chocolate and raisiny fruit in aroma and cup. A touch of citrus. Soft but lively acidity; silky mouthfeel. Deep, gently flavor saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Produced in the growing region surrounding the famous colonial city of Guatemala Antigua entirely from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.” Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A characteristically suave and quietly balanced coffee from the celebrated Antigua valley.

p1: Blind Assessment: Richly tart, resonantly complex. Orange, black currant, walnut, honeysuckle and jasmine in aroma and cup. Sweetly tart acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Long, deep finish, resonant with flavor.
p2: Notes: This coffee was produced exclusively from trees of one of Kenya’s premier varieties of Arabica, the great, Bourbon-related SL28. Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. ChacolaTAY is a Taiwanese small-batch roaster aiming to maximize cup character of elite green coffees through flexible, precise artisan roasting.  Visit http://chacolatay.com or call 886-935-730422 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those interested in sampling a superb example of the classic Kenya SL28 cup combining great sweetness, gently tart, pungent fruit and lush flowers.

p1: Blind Assessment: Delicate yet intense. Honey and tangerine-like citrus dominate; a pleasing salty-savory edge complicates the honeyish sweetness in the cup. Crisp, juicy acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Deeply sweet, tangerine-inflected finish.
p2: Notes: Produced mainly from trees of the admired, Bourbon-derived SL28 and SL34 varieties. In 2000, Ngunguru joined with its neighboring mills, Tegu and Karagoto, to form the Tekangu Cooperative. Based in the San Diego area, Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler that focuses on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was awarded the “2012 Roaster of the Year” title from Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Fine variant on the great Kenya profile: Vivacious, sweetly bright, juicy.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Lively, complex, comprehensive. Sweetly tart, juicy fruit notes (orange, guava), distinct dark chocolate, flowers, pungent fir in aroma and small cup. Lightly syrupy mouthfeel; chocolate and tart fruit tones in the finish. In two parts milk the chocolate note predictably dominates, complicated by a citrusy undercurrent.
p2: Notes: This coffee is a blend of three distinctive coffees, a pulped natural Brazil, a dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia Gesha, and a wet-processed Sulawesi. Seattle Coffee Works is a small-batch retail and wholesale roasting company, focused on quality and green coffee sourcing without compromise. Visit www.seattlecoffeeworks.com or call 206-340-8867 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Straight-shot drinkers may be particularly impressed by the complexity, range and balance of this blend, with its bright but smoothly juicy fruit notes wrapped in rounding chocolate and aromatic wood.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweet, delicate, honey-toned. Honey, molasses, night-blooming flowers, fresh-cut fir and an elegant, pistachio-like nut note in aroma and cup. Gently crisp acidity; light but very silky mouthfeel. Very clean, flavor-saturated finish slightly drying in the long.
p2: Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Geisha (also spelled Gesha). With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and chocolate cup, the Geisha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. This Gesha was processed by the orthodox wet or washed method, in which both skin and fruit flesh are removed from the beans or seeds before they are dried. ChacolaTAY is a Taiwanese small-batch roaster aiming to maximize cup character of elite green coffees through flexible, precise artisan roasting.  Visit http://chacolatay.com or call 886-935-730422 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those interested in sampling a delicately elegant but very distinctive variation on the great Gesha profile.

p1: Blind Assessment: Gently pungent, balanced. Aromatic oak, lemony citrus, hints of chocolate and flowers in aroma and cup. Round, quiet acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Hints of lemon and chocolate in a slightly drying finish.
p2: Notes: Five dollars (about 42% of the total price!) per bag sold of this coffee goes directly to Focus: HOPE, a celebrated human and civil rights program dedicated to practical solutions to problems of hunger, economic disparity, inadequate education and racial divisiveness in the city of Detroit, Michigan. This coffee is certified organically grown. Although the words "Fair Trade" appear on the label, judging by the absence of trademarked seal this coffee may not be certified Fair Trade by FairTrade USA (formerly TransFair USA). However, Higher Grounds is affiliated with the Fair Trade Federation, a membership (rather than certifying) organization devoted to "providing fair wages and good employment opportunities to economically disadvantaged artisans and farmers worldwide." The nicely-named Higher Grounds Trading Company specializes only in coffees that are certified Fair-Trade and organically grown.  Visit www.highergroundstrading.com or call 877-825-2262 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Persuasive local cause, nicely balanced cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Although described on the package as an espresso, this blend is evaluated here for non-espresso brewing. Roundly pungent, richly chocolaty. A complex chocolate sensation dominates in aroma and cup, with a savory hint of nut. Gently brisk acidity; light but smooth mouthfeel. Sweet, richly drying finish.
p2: Notes: A significant portion of the proceeds from this blend is donated to the charitable organization Grounds for Health that works to create sustainable cervical cancer prevention and treatment programs in coffee growing communities. Reunion Island Coffee is a quality-oriented roasting company founded by Canadian specialty coffee veteran Peter Pesce.  Visit www.reunionislandcoffee.com or call 800-565-5950 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy the natural, complex sweetness of roasted cocoa nib in a gently roast-rounded coffee.

coffee_name: Dominican Republic Cafe Femenino Organic Fair Trade
p1: Blind Assessment: Gentle, delicate. Crisp chocolate and hazelnut notes dominate in aroma and cup; complicating hints of fir and citrus. Gentle, balanced acidity; light, silky mouthfeel. Sweet-toned, slightly drying finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee is organic and Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. It is also offered under the umbrella of the Café Femenino program, which "provides extra income that goes directly to ... women producers." The grant-funded Café Femenino Foundation (www.cafefemeninofoundation.org) "supports efforts to improve the view of women's roles by supporting programs and projects that generate sales the women can control." In addition, twenty percent of the sales of this particular Café Femenino coffee is donated to the Griswold Residency of YWCA in Columbus, Ohio, a facility that offers a temporary home and assistance to low-income women in crisis (www.ywcacolumbus.org). Stauf’s is a micro-roaster in Columbus, Ohio founded in 1988 and serving wholesale and retail customers throughout the country.  Visit www.staufs.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Crisp, delicate cup offers impressive support for low-income women both in the Dominican Republic through the Café Femenino program and to local women in crisis in Columbus, Ohio.

p1: Blind Assessment: Delicately complex. Sweet cream and milk chocolate with balancing hints of grapefruity citrus and peppercorn. Round, rather muted acidity; lightly but distinctly syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet-toned, resonant, quietly flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: Five percent of sales of all Just Love coffees go to Waterstep, a non-profit dedicated to bringing clean, safe drinking water to people in developing nations. Additionally, 25 cents per bag of Cafe Femenino goes to Thistle Farms/Magdalene House, a women's crisis center. This coffee is also Fair Trade certified, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Café Femenino is an organization that supports women farmers and their families in coffee growing communities. Rwanda's impressive potential as fine coffee producer has come to fruition over the last several years owing to the industry of its growers, generous support from international aid agencies and the commitment of North American specialty coffee roasters. Just Love Coffee Roasters is a small-batch roaster located in Murfreesboro Tennessee; its mission is to develop the unique qualities inherent in each coffee bean and to be equally passionate about helping those in need.  Visit www.justlovecoffee.com or call 866-894-9463 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Unusual cup with quietly distinctive aroma and flavor contributing to an important cause.

p1: Blind Assessment: Complex and unorthodox. Sweet, orangy citrus and raw sugar in aroma and cup, with backgrounded hints of chocolate and baking spice. Quiet, round acidity; smooth, lively mouthfeel. Fades just a bit in a sweet-toned finish.
p2: Notes: Ten percent of sales of this coffee are donated to CancerCare, a national non-profit that provides free support services for those affected by cancer diagnosis, as a tribute to Amy Erickson, Caribou’s original roastmaster, who lost her battle with breast cancer in 1995 and whose story inspired the Amy’s Blend program. It will be sold and featured at Caribou throughout October, Breast Cancer Awareness month. This coffee also is 100% Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee.  Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A rather rough-edged but vigorous, engaging blend supporting a timely cause with personal resonance at Caribou.

p1: Blind Assessment: Round, sweet, gently pungent. Fresh-cut fir, chocolate, a hint of enlivening tart berry in aroma and cup. Round, rather muted acidity; light but syrupy mouthfeel. Sweet-toned, gently drying finish.
p2: Notes: Song Bird coffees are partnership coffees supporting The American Birding Association, with a portion of the proceeds donated to that Association. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price, but it is not certified “Bird Friendly” by the Smithsonian Migratory Bird Center. One of the country's pioneering socially and environmentally progressive roasters, Thanksgiving aimed to combine coffee quality with social and environmental responsibility many years before the latter preoccupations became fashionable. Visit www.thanksgivingcoffee.com or call 800-648-6491 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Gently lively cup for backyard birders and anyone who prefers mellow to bright.

p1: Blind Assessment: Round, low-toned, pungent. An oak-like aromatic wood note dominates in aroma and cup, with backgrounded caramel and milk chocolate sweetness and a hint of lily-like flowers. Quiet acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. Some flavor carries into a sweet though slightly drying finish.
p2: Notes: Produced by indigenous Mayan members of the ASOBAGRI cooperative. Certified organically grown and fair-traded, meaning farmers have been paid an economically sustainable price for this coffee based on internationally established price guidelines. Bicycle Coffee is a small-batch wholesale and retail roasting company started in 2009 by three brothers, a cousin, and a family friend. The Bicycle team roasts only organic and Fair Trade certified coffees in its hand-built roaster and delivers all of its coffee by bicycle, a practice it vows to maintain. In keeping with its community-based theme, Bicycle also sells its coffees for considerably less than the normal retail price at local farmers’ markets.  Visit www.bicyclecoffeeco.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a roundly pungent cup with relatively low acidity and who admire the uncompromisingly hands-on approach of this community-based roaster.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweetly and gently pungent. Prune, nut, chocolate, a hint of honey in aroma and cup. Round, quiet acidity; light but buttery-textured mouthfeel. Sweet-toned, simple finish.
p2: Notes: Processed by the pulped natural method, in which the skin is removed from the coffee fruit immediately after picking, but the seeds or beans are dried with the sweet pulp, or fruit flesh, still adhering to them. Produced entirely from trees of the heirloom Yellow Bourbon variety of Arabica. This coffee is Utz Certified, meaning it fulfills social, environmental and traceability standards embodied in the Utz Certified Code of Conduct. Nossa Familia donates one dollar per pound of coffee purchased to the consumer’s choice of seven different charitable organizations. Nossa Familia (“our family” in Portuguese) is an Oregon-based roaster that imports and roasts coffee from the family’s farms in Brazil. Visit www.nossacoffee.com or call 503-719-6605 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a gentle, roundly brisk cup offered by an idealistic branch of a six-generation Brazilian farming family.

p1: Blind Assessment: Pungent and perfumy. Orange zest, apricot, lush honeysuckle, fir, a hint of cocoa nib in aroma and cup. Roundly tart acidity; light, rather creamy-textured mouthfeel. Sweetly tart in the finish: hints of the orange and cocoa nib.
p2: Notes: This coffee was entirely produced from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica. PT’s Coffee donates one dollar per eight-ounce purchase to the Prodigy Youth Soccer Association of Topeka in honor of PT’s employee and soccer enthusiast Jonathan Kaspar, who lost his life in an automobile accident in 2010. The Flor Del Sol tattoo he wore on his arm inspired the name of this single-origin blend. Jose Antonio Salaverria of Las Ranas Estate, a direct trade partner of PT’s, donated the green coffee for this project. Roasted at PT’s Coffee, where the motto is “without the love, it’s just coffee.”  Visit www.ptscoffee.com or call 888-678-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy exhilarating aromatics, a briskly tart structure and grassroots soccer.

coffee_origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Original and complex. A pungent sweetness suggesting herb honey or agave syrup dominates, complicated by hints of night flowers, cocoa nib, cedar. Quietly crisp acidity; smooth, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor persists in a sweet-toned but gently drying finish.
p2: Notes: Sale of this coffee supports a fund to build a permanent monastery for monks of the Carmelite order in Montana, who pursue “an ancient, simple and agrarian form of life” that includes roasting coffees like this one. This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. This coffee is certified organically grown and Fair Trade, meaning it was purchased from small-holding farmers at a "fair" or economically sustainable price. Roastmaster Brother Java of Mystic Monk Coffee emphasizes his artisan approach to roasting and his commitment to quality. This is one of Mystic Monk’s Coffees of the Month series.  Visit www.mysticmonkcoffee.com or call 877-751-6377 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: An unusual dried-in-the-fruit profile, honeyish but pungent and deep. Nice any time, but should make an exceptional late-in-the-day cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Bright, complex, floral-toned. In the small cup gently tart citrus, stone fruit, vanilla-toned chocolate with lush floral top notes. Full, creamy mouthfeel. Flowers, fruit and chocolate all persist in a resonant finish. Two parts milk round the fruit and flowers toward chocolate.
p2: Notes: Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees through the roasting process and all the way to the cup.  Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Intense but balanced espresso, dynamic in the small cup and suavely complex in short milk.

p1: Blind Assessment: Complex, original, deeply sweet-toned. Symphonic fruit notes suggest melon, cidery pear, mint, apricot, even banana. Smoothly rich acidity; full, buoyantly lively mouthfeel. Fruit consolidates toward chocolate in a simplifying but resonant finish.
p2: Notes: Most Yirgacheffe coffee is prepared by the conventional wet method, in which the skin and pulp are removed from the beans or seeds before they are dried, encouraging a cleanly high-toned, often intensely floral- and citrus-toned cup. This Yirgacheffe is a "natural" or dry-processed version, however, meaning the beans/seeds were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a deeper-toned profile, more pungent than bright though still extravagant in its aromatics. Produced by Ninety-Plus Estates in Ethiopia. Thirty-Thirty is a small-batch coffee roasting company located in Peoria Illinois that is committed to sourcing the finest green coffees and to expressing the individuality and character of those coffees through the roasting process and all the way to the cup.  Visit www.thirty-thirtycoffee.com or call 309-713-2983 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Aficionados interested in sampling one of the most original and striking dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopian coffees to appear this year.

p1: Blind Assessment: Intense lime-toned citrus, lush flowers, nut-toned chocolate, peach in aroma and cup. Gently tart acidity; silky mouthfeel. Chocolate and lime carry into a sweet-toned finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee, from the Yirgacheffe growing region, was purchased directly from the Yirgacheffe Coffee Farmers Cooperative Union, a collection of cooperatives with a total of nearly 45,000 active members, rather than through the Ethiopian Commodity Exchange (ECX). Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. Coffea Roasterie is a South Dakota-based wholesale and retail roaster, offering a small but refined selection of mostly single-origin coffees.  Visit www.coffearoasterie.com or call 605-362-9955 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A fine variation on the classic washed Yirgacheffe profile, with exhilarating lime and lush floral notes.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Gently bright and pungent in the small cup: fresh-cut cedar, buttery chocolate, night flowers, hints of apricot and pear. Impressively creamy mouthfeel; rich, flavor-saturated finish. Retains its buttery richness in two parts milk, with flavor dominated by a crisp dark chocolate.
p2: Notes: This lot is comprised entirely of the admired Pacamara variety of Arabica, a cross between the giant-beaned Maragogipe and Pacas, a selection of the heirloom Bourbon. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy a straight shot with full but lively mouthfeel and a balanced complexity.

coffee_origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidama Province, Ethiopia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Intense, original, complex. Fresh-cut cedar, grape, blueberry, brandy, roasted cocoa nib in the exhilarating aroma and flavor. Dry, berry-toned acidity; silky mouthfeel. Flavor resolves toward a fruit-toned chocolate in a long finish.
p2: Notes: Grown in the Guji Zone of Sidama Province, this Ethiopian coffee is a dry- or "natural-" processed coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit was removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. This coffee won first place at the Ethiopia Taste of Harvest Competition in 2010. Coffea Roasterie is a South Dakota-based wholesale and retail roaster, offering a small but refined selection of mostly single-origin coffees. Visit www.coffearoasterie.com or call 605-362-9955 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy the extravagant intensity of southern Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit coffees.

coffee_name: El Salvador Las Delicias Pacamara SOE Blend
coffee_origin: Nejapa, San Salvador Department, El Salvador.
p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Complex but balanced. In the small cup fruit suggestions range from zesty tangerine to rounder plum and banana, with floral top notes and a pungent fresh-cut cedar. Lightly syrupy mouthfeel; fruit and cedar resolve toward chocolate in a long, clean finish. Two parts milk further develop the chocolate tendency with continued plum and citrus complication.
p2: Notes: This lot is comprised entirely of the Pacamara variety of Arabica, a cross between the giant-beaned Maragogipe and Pacas, a selection of the heirloom Bourbon. A blend of different screen sizes from the same trees, with each screen size roasted separately then blended to formula. Water Avenue Coffee is a tiny roastery nestled next to the railway in the old Industrial Southeast quarter in Portland, Oregon. Visit www.wateravenuecoffee.com or call 503-808-7083 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A fine, versatile espresso with great range and depth of sensation yet fundamental balance and completeness.

p1: Blind Assessment: Intense, exhilaratingly complex, resonant. A cascade of floral notes ranging in suggestion from bitter lavender to lush honeysuckle. Honey, tangerine, and a crisp, cocoaish chocolate. Round, richly stated acidity; syrupy, lively mouthfeel. Deep, flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: This is a non-auction lot of Esmeralda Gesha (also spelled Geisha) from Hacienda La Esmeralda, the producer that first introduced the celebrated Gesha variety of Arabica to the world. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. This Gesha was processed by the orthodox wet or washed method, in which both skin and fruit flesh are removed from the beans or seeds before they are dried. This coffee is 100% Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee. Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: An opportunity to taste the spectacular Gesha profile at peak complexity and nuance. Reasonably priced for an Esmeralda Gesha.

coffee_origin: Canas Verdes, Boquete growing region, western Panama.
p1: Blind Assessment: Intense, complex floral notes (lavender, lily), tangerine-like fruit, honey, cinnamon-like spice, fresh-cut fir in aroma and cup. Bright, juicy acidity; silky mouthfeel. The finish is drying but profoundly flavor-saturated.
p2: Notes: This is a lot of Esmeralda Gesha (also spelled Geisha) from Hacienda La Esmeralda, the producer that first introduced the celebrated Gesha variety of Arabica to the world; it represents a mix of the Esmeralda Gesha production that was not included in the producer’s yearly auction. With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. This Gesha was processed by the orthodox wet or washed method, in which both skin and fruit flesh are removed from the beans or seeds before they are dried. Calgary-based Fratello is a second-generation boutique coffee roaster owned by three brothers who focus on responsible trade relationships with coffee growers.  Visit www.fratellocoffee.com or call 800-944-2545 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Super aficionados on a budget. A (believe it or not) reasonably priced version of the extravagantly distinctive and rare Esmeralda Gesha.

p1: Blind Assessment: Rich, brandy-like fruit with suggestions of honey, almond, dark chocolate, cherry and more in aroma and cup. Round, wine-like acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Brandy and chocolate in particular persist in a sweet finish.
p2: Notes: Most Yirgacheffe coffee is prepared by the conventional wet method, in which the skin and pulp are removed from the beans or seeds before they are dried, encouraging a cleanly high-toned, often intensely floral- and citrus-toned cup. This Yirgacheffe is a "natural" or dry-processed version, however, meaning the beans/seeds were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a more idiosyncratic profile more pungent than bright though still extravagant in its aromatics. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this striking and unusual coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Calgary-based Fratello is a second-generation boutique coffee roaster owned by three brothers who focus on responsible trade relationships with coffee growers.  Visit www.fratellocoffee.com or call 800-944-2545 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: An adventurer’s coffee, deeply and idiosyncratically complex with aromatic surprises from aroma through finish.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Impressively sweet and complex. Roundly low-acid fruit (plum, banana, and grape), crisp citrus and earthy chocolate in aroma and small cup. Balanced, lightly creamy mouthfeel; rich, bittersweet fruit in the finish. Pungently authoritative in two parts milk with continuing suggestions of fruit, chocolate and citrus.
p2: Notes: This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Roasted by The Coffee Academics, an irreverent sibling of Hong Kong’s popular homegrown coffee brand Caffè HABITU. The JWF blend reflects the taste of Caffè HABITU’s chairperson and founder Jennifer Liu. Visit www.the-academics.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Appealingly complex and deep as a straight shot. Simplifies in milk, but maintains authority and fruit-toned character.

p1: Blind Assessment: Spicy, delicate, complex. Orange, savory spice, honey, night flowers in aroma and cup. Gently lively acidity; very smooth, delicately syrupy mouthfeel. Orange in particular persists in a very sweet, long finish.
p2: Notes: A “natural” or dry-processed coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile that is lower-toned and more pungent than the more familiar wet-processed floral- and citrus-toned southern Ethiopia profile. Certified organically grown, this coffee is processed with great care by Ethiopia's only female coffee mill owner, Asnakech Thomas, who pays high prices for ripe cherry from smallholders in Ethiopia's Amaro region. The West Bean is a San Diego-based roastery founded by two friends with a passion for coffee and a determination to bring their customers the highest quality hand-crafted coffee possible. Visit www.thewestbean.com or call 619-709-3232 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Aficionados interested in a very cleanly and originally expressed version of the Ethiopia natural cup; anyone who enjoys exotic but balanced complexity.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Rich, balanced, tart. Sweet dark chocolate and deep, almost savory floral tones balanced by tart berry in aroma and small cup. Smooth, lightly creamy mouthfeel. A buttery chocolate dominates in the finish and carries with pungent authority into two parts milk.
p2: Notes: This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Roasted by The Coffee Academics, an irreverent sibling of Hong Kong’s popular homegrown coffee brand Caffè HABITU. The Academics blend represents the humility of an academician and his pursuit of lifelong learning. Visit www.the-academics.com for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy an espresso that balances tart authority with chocolaty sweetness.

p1: Blind Assessment: Spicy floral notes (lavender, tea rose), dark chocolate, honey, hazelnut, and a pungent mango-like fruit in aroma and cup. Rich, juicy acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. The finish is bittersweet and drying in the short, but flavor and sweetness reassert themselves in the long.
p2: Notes: Most Yirgacheffe coffee is prepared by the conventional wet method, in which the skin and pulp are removed from the beans or seeds before they are dried, encouraging a cleanly high-toned, often intensely floral- and citrus-toned cup. This Yirgacheffe is a "natural" or dry-processed version, however, meaning the beans/seeds were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile more pungent than bright though still extravagant in its floral-toned aromatics. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this striking and unusual coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Victrola is a small-batch, hands-on roaster with a passionate commitment to quality and distinctiveness. Visit www.victrolacoffee.com or call 206-624-1725 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy sensory excitement and surprise.

p1: Blind Assessment: Richly structured coffee with an intense balance of sweet, bitter and tart tastes supporting complex aromatics: lavender-like flowers, pecan, fresh-cut fir, and most strikingly, an unusual fruit note simultaneously suggesting mango and melon. Rich, deep acidity; lively, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. The complex fruit note in particular carries into a drying but sweet finish.
p2: Notes: Most Yirgacheffe coffee is prepared by the conventional wet method, in which the skin and pulp are removed from the beans or seeds before they are dried, encouraging a cleanly high-toned, often intensely floral- and citrus-toned cup. This Yirgacheffe is a "natural" or dry-processed version, however, meaning the beans/seeds were dried inside the fruit, encouraging a flavor profile more pungent than bright though still extravagant in its floral-toned aromatics. Like virtually all Ethiopia coffees, this striking and unusual coffee is produced by villagers on small, garden plots interplanted with food and other subsistence crops. Seattle Coffee Works is a small-batch retail and wholesale roasting company, focused on quality and green coffee sourcing without compromise. Visit www.seattlecoffeeworks.com or call 206-340-8867 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who can handle both intensity and complexity in a striking and unusual coffee.

p1: Blind Assessment: Rich, balanced, a hint of red wine. Fresh-cut cedar, black-currant-like fruit, brown sugar, hints of chocolate and red wine in aroma and cup. Round, wine-toned acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Quiet, sweet-toned finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee was processed using the honey method, which means that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but all or some of the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. It is a Rainforest Alliance certified coffee, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Klatch Coffee is an award-winning small-batch roasting company in the Los Angeles area whose resident barista and trainer, Heather Perry, won both the 2003 and 2007 United States Barista Championships brewing a Klatch Coffee espresso blend.  Visit www.klatchroasting.com or call 877-455-2824 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A contemplative sort of coffee, deep, quiet, sweet without sentiment.

p1: Blind Assessment: Complex, deeply expressed aroma: molasses, dark chocolate, slightly scorched cedar, a hit of flowers. Richly tart acidity; heavy, syrupy mouthfeel. The complex aromatics carry into cup and finish, where a tart astringency jostles with a continued chocolate-and-molasses sweetness.
p2: Notes: This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Uganda, situated in the Great Lakes region of central Africa at the headwaters of the Nile, is the original home of Coffea canephora, or Robusta. Uganda also produces excellent wet-processed Arabicas, however, like this one grown by villagers on small plots. Green Mountain Coffee Roasters is one of the country's leading specialty roasters, offering a particularly wide-ranging variety of origins and roast styles. Visit www.GreenMountainCoffee.com or call 888-879-4627 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy deep, authoritative, richly stated coffees with a hint of roasty pungency.

p1: Blind Assessment: Very sweet, deeply and subtly complex. Lush night flowers, aromatic woods, tangerine, mint-toned cocoa in aroma and cup. Richly nuanced acidity; full, syrupy mouthfeel. A savory tendency is particularly noticeable in a resonant, gently drying finish.
p2: Notes: Produced from trees of the rare Ethiopia-derived botanical variety Gesha (also spelled Geisha). With its generally elongated beans and distinctive floral and crisp, often chocolaty cup, the Gesha variety continues to distinguish itself as one of the world's most unique coffees. This is a dry-processed or "natural" version, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Based in the San Diego area, Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler that focuses on organic and socially responsible coffees; it was awarded the “2012 Roaster of the Year” title from Roast Magazine. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who can afford a finely executed dried-in-the-fruit version of the great Gesha profile.

p1: Blind Assessment: Very sweet, gently tart. Complex blackberry and black currant notes with a hint of lemony citrus. Delicate, sweet-toned acidity; very silky, buoyant mouthfeel. Simplifies in the finish, though retains balance and sweetness.
p2: Notes: Like all Caribou coffees, this one is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. It is one of Caribou’s Roastmaster Reserve coffees, special seasonal offerings. Caribou Coffee is a retail roasting chain based in the upper Middle West whose rather irreverent motto "Life is short. Stay awake for it" belies a serious approach to coffee.  Visit www.cariboucoffee.com or call 888-227-4268 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: An easy-going Kenya, with the sweetly tart berry character of fine Kenyas but without their often challengingly bright acidity.

coffee_origin: Volcan de Santa Ana regioin, El Salvador.
p1: Blind Assessment: Soft, delicate. Orange and milk chocolate suggestions in aroma and cup. Gently round acidity; smooth though slightly lean mouthfeel. Flavor persists in a quietly resonant finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee was processed using the pulped natural variation on the honey method, meaning that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry in its entirety on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. Joe Van Gogh is a small-batch roasting company with a focus on certified organic coffees. In addition to its Internet retail, it operates three coffeehouses in Durham and Chapel Hill, North Carolina.  Visit www.joevangogh.com or call 919-644-0111 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy subtle, gentle beverages.

coffee_name: Costa Rica La Candelilla Honey Peaberry
p1: Blind Assessment: Delicate, crisply sweet-toned. Fresh-cut fir, apricot, brown sugar and chocolate in aroma and cup. Gently and sweetly tart acidity; silky mouthfeel. Sweetness outlasts a drying astringency in the finish.
p2: Notes: Grown and processed on the La Candelilla Estate in Costa Rica’s famous Tarrazú growing region. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. Processed using the honey method, which means that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but all or some of the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. The Roasterie is a longtime leading, quality-oriented specialty roaster that emphasizes its commitment to "air roasting," a technology utilizing a column of hot air rather than the conventional turning drum to agitate the roasting beans.  Visit www.theroasterie.com or call 800-376-0245 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy white wines that are delicate and crisply dry yet sweet.

coffee_name: Costa Rica El Espino Yellow Honey Caturra
coffee_origin: Zarcero Canton, Alajuela Province, Costa Rica.
p1: Blind Assessment: Nicely balanced, gently and tartly sweet. Nut, fresh-cut oak, orange, pear perhaps, raw sugar in aroma and cup. Soft acidity; smooth, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Simple finish with some richness.
p2: Notes: From trees of the sturdy Caturra variety of Arabica. Processed by the yellow variation of the honey method, which means that the outer skin of the coffee fruit is removed as it is in the wet process, after which some but not all of the sticky fruit residue is mechanically removed, allowing a thin layer to remain on the bean during drying. Willoughby's Coffee & Tea is a pioneer specialty coffee roaster established in the early 1980s that has gracefully and successfully moved with the times and now offers a menu of extremely refined small-lot, single-origin coffees. Visit www.willoughbyscoffee.com or call 800-388-8400 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those who enjoy subtly sweet breakfast coffees with understated acidity.

p1: Blind Assessment: Very sweet, deeply pungent. Blackberry, black currant, fir, with a backgrounded dark chocolate in aroma and cup. Pungent though rather muted acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Richly drying finish.
p2: Notes: In El Salvador the acronym SHG (Strictly High Grown) refers to coffee produced at elevations above 4,000 feet (1,200 meters). This coffee was produced exclusively from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica and processed using the honey method, which means that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but all or some of the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. With two locations in Southern California's Orange County, Kéan Coffee is an in-house coffee roaster and retailer established by Martin Diedrich of the distinguished Diedrich coffee family. The Kéan slogan, "Martin knows his beans" should be true, considering Martin grew up in Guatemala where his family owned a coffee farm. Visit www.keancoffee.com or call 949-933-9164 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: The honey process deepens and rounds the characteristically tart Bourbon fruit, making this a good choice for aficionados exploring a variation on the great Bourbon profile, and for anyone who prefers rich pungency to bright acidity.

coffee_origin: Mozonte district, Nuevo Segovia Department, Nicaragua.
p1: Blind Assessment: Quiet but engaging. Molasses, ripe orange, almond, aromas of moist, old forest wood. Gently rich, round acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Simple but resonantly sweet finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee was processed using the pulped natural variation on the honey method, meaning that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry in its entirety on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. Located in Everett, Washington, north of Seattle, Velton's Coffee is a quality-focused small-batch wholesale roaster. Visit www.veltonscoffee.com or call 206-250-6130 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Aficionados interested in a coffee with a subtly unusual profile, a little Sumatra-like, a little natural-Brazil-like, but ultimately unique in its damply woodsy and nut-toned character.

p1: Blind Assessment: Gently crisp, refreshingly balanced. Freshly cut aromatic wood, dark chocolate and a faint tart berry note in aroma and cup. Quiet, softly expressed acidity; lightly creamy mouthfeel. Aromatically simple but balanced, resonant finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee comes exclusively from trees of the heirloom Red Bourbon variety of Arabica, and was processed using the honey method, which means that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but all or some of the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. Water Avenue Coffee is a tiny roastery nestled next to the railway in the old Industrial Southeast quarter in Portland, Oregon. Visit www.wateravenuecoffee.com or call 503-808-7083 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A subtle coffee subtly light-roasted produces a crisply delicate, refreshing cup.

coffee_name: Costa Rica Herbazu Villa Sarchi Honey
coffee_origin: West Valley growing region, Costa Rica.
p1: Blind Assessment: Sweetly pungent, balanced, honey-toned. Almond, orange, honey, a hint of minty chocolate in aroma and cup. Delicate, fruit-toned acidity; silky mouthfeel. Orange and honey in particular carry into a rich finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee is produced exclusively from trees of the Villa Sarchi variety of Arabica, a dwarf mutation of the heirloom Bourbon variety. It was processed using the honey method, which means that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but all or some of the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. Herbazu is an admired micro mill that pioneered preparing small-lot coffee selectively by variety and processing method. Olympia Coffee Roasting is a small-batch wholesale and retail roasting company with a youthful, no-nonsense style and a commitment to high quality organic coffees.  Visit www.olympiacoffeeroasting.com or call 360-753-0066 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Honey character in a honey coffee; a walk in the woods in the springtime.

p1: Blind Assessment: Subtly extravagant. Rich night flowers, crisp cocoa, hints of tangerine and fir in aroma and cup. Quiet acidity; syrupy mouthfeel. Rich, flavor-saturated finish turns slightly heavy in the long.
p2: Notes: This coffee was entirely produced from trees of the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica and was processed using the honey method, which means that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but all or some of the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. This coffee is Rainforest Alliance certified, meaning it was produced following sustainable ecological and socio-economic criteria developed by the Sustainable Agricultural Network, a coalition of independent, environment-focused non-governmental organizations. Klatch Coffee is an award-winning small-batch roasting company in the Los Angeles area whose resident barista and trainer, Heather Perry, won both the 2003 and 2007 United States Barista Championships brewing a Klatch Coffee espresso blend.  Visit www.klatchroasting.com or call 877-455-2824 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Coffee iconoclasts. Complex and unexpected.

coffee_name: El Salvador La Roxanita Pulped Natural
p1: Blind Assessment: Intense, tartly sweet, richly dry. Tart berry leads in aroma and cup, softened by a minty dark chocolate and a hint of cedar. Roundly bright acidity; silky mouthfeel. Chocolate in particular carries into a sweet finish.
p2: Notes: This lot is comprised entirely of the Pacamara variety of Arabica, a cross between the giant-beaned Maragogipe and Pacas, a selection of the heirloom Bourbon. This coffee was processed using the pulped natural variation on the honey method, meaning that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry in its entirety on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. Caffe Ladro is a Seattle-based small-batch roaster committed to sustainably and ethically produced coffee. Visit www.caffeladro.com or call 866-343-9786 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Very sweet, quite tart; those who don’t normally care for tartly acidy coffees may be persuaded by this deep, richly subtle rendition.

coffee_origin: Apaneca district, Ahuachapan Department, El Salvador.
p1: Blind Assessment: Dark chocolate, cherry, oak, night flowers, a hint of brandy in aroma and cup. Roundly bright, complexly expressed acidity; lightly creamy mouthfeel. Dark chocolate carries distinctly into a savory-sweet finish.
p2: Notes: This coffee was processed using the honey method, which means that the outer skin is removed as it is in the wet process, but all or some of the sticky fruit residue is allowed to dry on the bean and later removed by machine along with the parchment skin. Temple Coffee is a quality-focused retail and wholesale roaster in Sacramento, California who has been voted Best Coffee House since 2005 by the Sacramento News & Review.  Visit www.templecoffee.com or call 916-454-1282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Lovers of fruity, lightly fermented dried-in-the-fruit “natural” coffees should particularly enjoy this coffee, which treads the same sensory track as fruity naturals but with a bit more subtlety.

p1: Blind Assessment: Extravagant aroma and flavor dominated by very complexly expressed floral notes, honey, pungent dried orange and bergamot. Sweetly tart acidity; delicate, lively mouthfeel. Honeyish short finish turns a little tight and drying in the long.
p2: Notes: ECX refers to the recently established Ethiopia Commodity Exchange; this is a top-rated lot from the Exchange. Ethiopia coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. Calgary-based Fratello is a second-generation boutique coffee roaster owned by three brothers who focus on responsible trade relationships with coffee growers.  Visit www.fratellocoffee.com or call 800-944-2545 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Those in pursuit of intensity; a flamboyant and bracing cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweetly pungent, deep. Baker’s chocolate, hints of strawberry, orange, flowers, honey in aroma and cup. Quietly rounded acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Rich, cocoa-toned finish.
p2: Notes: A micro-lot from one field of Miguel Rojas’s farm, a field called “Miso,” specially selected by Fratello. From trees of the Caturra and Typica varieties of Arabica.  Calgary-based Fratello is a second-generation boutique coffee roaster owned by three brothers who focus on responsible trade relationships with coffee growers.  Visit www.fratellocoffee.com or call 800-944-2545 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Not a showy cup, but a quietly complex, quite comfortable one.

p1: Blind Assessment: Sweetly crisp, gentle. Fresh-cut cedar, molasses-influenced dark chocolate and a hint of flowers in aroma and cup. Roundly soft acidity; lightish but supple mouthfeel. Cleanly sweet finish.
p2: Notes: Mocha Java is the world’s earliest blend. It combined the only two coffees available in the world in the 17th century: “Mocha” from Yemen and Java from the Dutch colony in what is now Indonesia. Today versions of the Mocha Java blend often substitute an Ethiopia coffee for the Yemen and a Sumatra coffee for the Java. Green Mountain Coffee Roasters is one of the country's leading specialty roasters, offering a particularly wide-ranging variety of origins and roast styles. VVisit www.GreenMountainCoffee.com or call 888-879-4627 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A quiet but delicately complex morning cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: (As brewed in a Keurig B70 Platinum single-serve brewing device using a "K-Cup" capsule to produce a 6-ounce serving). Subtle night flowers and faint chocolate play out against a roasty backdrop in the aroma. The flowers persist and the chocolate turns sweet and caramelly in the cup. A hint of juiciness in a roast-muted acidity. Light but smooth mouthfeel. Sweet charry roastiness in the finish.
p2: Notes: Keurig brewing devices were among the first single-serve brewers on the market, starting in the mid 1990's with office models and now available in five home models with a variety of features and price points. Barista Prima Coffeehouse is a brand of coffee roasted and sold by Green Mountain with the motto “European coffee artistry in your favorite cup.” The K-Cups in the Barista Prima collection pack more coffee into the capsule than even the “Extra Bold” K-Cup, with the intention of producing a more intense flavor profile. Keurig/Green Mountain, formerly Green Mountain Coffee Roasters, pioneered single-serve capsule brewing in the United States with its Keurig brewing system, and remains one of the country’s leading large specialty roasters, offering a particularly wide-ranging variety of origins and roast styles. Visit www.GreenMountainCoffee.com or call 888-879-4627 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A subtle, floral-toned dark roast for Keurig owners.

p1: Blind Assessment: Evaluated as espresso. Rich, deep, chocolaty, with an apricot fruit and a hint of pungent cedar. Buttery mouthfeel; chocolate-toned finish. Maintains flavor well in two parts milk, though the fruit and chocolate turn surprisingly tart and dry.
p2: Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. This sample consists entirely of peaberries, a kind of bean that results when the coffee fruit develops only a single, oval bean rather than the usual pair of flat-sided beans. Peaberries produce a somewhat different (often better) cup than normal beans from the same crop, from which they may or may not be separated during grading. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A superbly deep and balanced single-origin, straight-shot espresso, with the acidity turned from assertive to roundly rich by a skillful roast.

coffee_origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.
p1: Blind Assessment: Superb aromatics and flavor: A rich, fudgy chocolate sensation dominates, with flowers, vanilla, hints of brandy and tart, guava-like fruit. Round, crisp acidity; dense, full mouthfeel. The finish is very sweet and vanilla-laced in the short, though in the long it fades toward astringency.
p2: Notes: This is a dry-processed or "natural" coffee, meaning the beans were dried inside the fruit rather than after the fruit has been removed, as is the case with wet-processed or "washed" coffees. Based in the San Diego area, Bird Rock Coffee Roasters is a retailer and wholesaler that focuses on organic and socially responsible coffees. Visit www.birdrockcoffee.com or call 858-551-1707 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Impressively rich and complexly chocolate-toned variation on the dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia cup.

p1: Blind Assessment: Honey-toned, juicy. Flowers, tangerine-like fruit, a hint of baker’s chocolate in aroma and cup. Richly and gently bright acidity; lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Flavor carries into a tart, rather drying finish.
p2: Notes: Yirgacheffe is a coffee region in southern Ethiopia that produces distinctively floral- and fruit-toned coffees from traditional varieties of Arabica long grown in the region. Yirgacheffe coffees like this one processed by the wet or washed method (fruit skin and pulp is removed before drying) typically express great aromatic complexity and intensity with a particular emphasis on citrus and floral notes. Beansmith Coffee is a small-batch roasting company located in La Vista, Nebraska that believes coffee drinkers should know as much as they can about the coffee they drink, and that there is a story behind every cup, one worth exploring. Visit www.beansmith.com or call 866-663-5295 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: A quiet but distinctive Yirgacheffe that should please those who like their flowers, citrus and cocoa in balance, present but not insistent.

p1: Blind Assessment: Honey, pungent cocoa-toned chocolate, lavender-like top notes in aroma and cup. Gently brisk acidity; supple, silky mouthfeel. Flowers and honey in particular carry into a sweet, resonant finish.
p2: Notes: Despite grower discontent and urban encroachment on prime coffee lands, Kenya continues to produce some of the world's most elegant and distinctive coffees. AA is the highest grade of Kenya coffee based on bean size and freedom from defect. JBC Coffee Roasters (formerly Johnson Brothers Coffee Roasters) is a distinguished small-batch roasting company. Visit www.jbccoffeeroasters.com or call 608-256-5282 for more information.
p3: Who Should Drink It: Sweet but crisp variant on the great Kenya profile.

p1: Blind Assessment: Spectacularly and complexly sweet: honey, lilac-like flowers, candied orange, balanced by a crisp roasted cocoa-nib-like chocolate. Delicate but rich acidity; round, lightly syrupy mouthfeel. Very sweet, long, flavor-saturated finish.
p2: Notes: The Nanno Challa Cooperative of small-holding farmers grows heirloom varieties of Arabica native to the region, varieties noted for their often intense floral and citrus character.
